texts: Just as he approached him, the man glanced quickly up and down the street, then took a small item from his pocket and tossed it over the fence before continuing on to the station. The 'chink' of the object hitting the ground piqued the interest of a man in the ditch, who found a ring. Kellett claims this story, but Lowen denies it vehemently. There is a possibility that he encountered Davenheim in the lane, but Poirot finds it highly unlikely. Japp agrees, noting that Lowen's actions seem odd. Poirot suggests that the ring could have been planted near the scene. Japp mentions a lime kiln nearby that could have been used to dispose of the body. Poirot contemplates the situation, leaving Japp and the narrator puzzled.

The man tending to the garden was clearly agitated by our presence, but begrudgingly agreed to assist us. After an unbearable delay, he presented us with some stale pastries and lukewarm tea before retreating back to his gardening. As soon as he left, a swarm of hungry cats surrounded us, meowing incessantly. Feeling sorry for the starving creatures, I offered them bits of cake which they devoured eagerly. Pouring what little milk we had into a saucer caused the cats to fight over it ferociously. "They're clearly malnourished!" I exclaimed in outrage.

As we approached the town of Merlinville, a sense of unease crept over me. My companion, with a grave expression, muttered about a looming disaster that he could not quite explain. Despite my skepticism, his words left a chill in the air. He hinted at a big affair, a complex problem that would not be easily resolved. Just then, we reached Merlinville and sought directions to the Villa Geneviève. A local pointed us in the right direction, guiding us through the town towards our destination.

With a cry of terror piercing the night, the girl vanished through the window, her wrists like steel. Poirot, impatient, brushed Françoise aside and hurried down the passage to the other maids. The door was locked from the inside, but a heavy fall was heard. Eventually, Cinderella opened the door to reveal Mrs. Renauld gasping for breath on the bed. She had been nearly strangled. Poirot examined a silk rope ladder - a means of escape. Meanwhile, a figure lay dead on the ground, revealed to be the beautiful Marthe Daubreuil. Confused memories flooded my mind as Poirot reprimanded Françoise for not disclosing Mrs. Renauld's change of room. The chaos culminated in Poirot demanding the doctor for Mrs. Renauld and then the police.

As Giraud laid his hat on the table and prepared to deliver his lecture on detective work, Poirot settled in to listen attentively. Giraud confidently outlined his case against Jack Renauld, detailing the motives and means that led to his arrest. But Poirot, with a glint of mischief in his eye, interjected with a crucial detail that Giraud had overlooked. The two men engaged in a battle of wits, each trying to outsmart the other with their theories and deductions. As they walked towards the sea to review the case, Poirot guided Hastings towards the truth with his characteristic cryptic remarks. It was a challenging and exhilarating intellectual exercise, where every detail mattered, and every clue led them closer to unraveling the mystery.

"So, what do we know about Rayburn? He's got a scar, sure, but that could easily be a fake. He fits the height and build profile though. Can you remember the details of the head you described to the police at Scotland Yard?" My heart raced. Suzanne was intelligent and well-educated, but I hoped she wasn't familiar with the technical jargon of anthropology. "Dolichocephalic," I replied casually. Suzanne seemed uncertain. "Are you sure?" "Absolutely. It means long-headed, with a width less than 75 percent of its length," I explained smoothly. There was a moment of silence.

Poirot's conversation with the doctor turned to the ancient beliefs of Egypt, causing tension among the group. Despite the doctor's skepticism, Poirot's interest in the supernatural was evident. As they explored the excavations, a sense of unease lingered in the air. Hassan, a servant, warned Poirot of evil spirits present and urged the young master to leave. The sighting of a shadowy figure resembling Anubis, the god of departing souls, heightened the group's fear. Dr. Ames and Sir Guy attempted to catch the mysterious figure but found no trace of its existence. Poirot, unfazed by the events, focused on ensuring his safety in his own unique way.

"After the bonds went missing from the trunk, a thorough search of the ship was conducted but yielded no results. It was discovered that the stolen bonds were sold in small parcels shortly after the ship docked in New York. This led to suspicions falling on Mr. Ridgeway. He was then searched and questioned, but the mystery remained unsolved. Determined to get to the bottom of this, Monsieur Hercule Poirot and his friend Captain Hastings decided to pay a visit to the Bank. Upon arrival, they were escorted to a small office where they met the joint general managers, Mr. Vavasour and Mr. Shaw, both of whom had dedicated their lives to the service of the Bank."

” I tried to follow his instructions, reviewing every aspect of the investigation. After careful consideration, it became apparent to me that Giraud's theory, which Poirot dismissed, was the most logical explanation. Contemplating further, I realized that the key to the puzzle likely lay with Madame Daubreuil. Giraud was unaware of her involvement in the Beroldy Case, a detail Poirot emphasized as crucial. Focused on this new lead, I felt a surge of hope. Then, a sudden burst of inspiration struck me, causing me to tremble as I pieced together a new theory."

“You instructed me to secure Cabin 17,” Pagett hesitated, evoking memories of bravery in the face of danger. With a hint of irritation, I responded, “I simply noted that No. 17 was available. But there was no need for you to defend it as if your life depended on it. Cabins 13 or 28 would have sufficed.” His expression turned pained. “There is something more,” he persisted. “Miss Beddingfeld was assigned the cabin, yet this morning I witnessed Chichester exiting it discreetly.” I fixed him with a stern gaze. “If you are trying to stir up baseless rumors about Chichester, a missionary albeit a disagreeable one, and the charming Anne Beddingfeld, I refuse to entertain such gossip,” I stated coolly. “Anne Beddingfeld is a delightful young lady with exceptional legs. I dare say she possesses the finest legs aboard.” Pagett was clearly uncomfortable with my mention of Anne Beddingfeld’s legs. He was not one to notice legs himself, or if he did, he would never admit it. Additionally, he viewed my interest in such matters as frivolous. Enjoying his discomfort, I continued mischievously, “Now that you have made her acquaintance, why not invite her to join us for dinner at our table tomorrow evening? It is the Fancy Dress ball, after all. And do visit the barber to select a costume for me.” “Surely you are not considering attending in fancy dress?” Pagett exclaimed in horror. It was evident that such a notion clashed with his perception of my dignity. He appeared scandalized and distressed. Although I had not originally planned on wearing fancy dress, the opportunity to disconcert Pagett was too enticing to resist. “What do you mean?” I retorted. “Of course I shall dress up. And so will you.” Pagett recoiled in horror. “Go to the barber and make the arrangements,” I concluded. “I doubt they will have sizes to accommodate my stature,” Pagett remarked, eyeing me critically. Unintentionally, Pagett could be quite tactless on occasion. “And reserve a table for six in the dining hall,” I instructed. “We shall invite the Captain, the lady with the lovely legs, Mrs. Blair—” “You will not secure Mrs. Blair’s company without Colonel Race,” Pagett interrupted. “He has already asked her to dine with him.” Pagett seemed to possess knowledge of everything. I was understandably irritated. “Who is this Race?” I demanded, frustrated. As I had mentioned earlier, Pagett always seemed to be in the know. He assumed a mysterious demeanor once more. “They say he is a Secret Service agent, Sir Eustace. Quite a prominent figure. But I cannot confirm it.” “Typical of the Government, isn’t it?” I exclaimed. “They entrust secret documents to a civilian, when all he desires is to be left in peace.” Pagett adopted an even more secretive air, moving closer and lowering his voice.

So long as there was supposed to be only one weapon, no suspicion was likely to attach to the girl who had had the second paper-knife in her possession. He was valiantly shielding the woman he had once loved but at what a cost to himself! I began to realize the magnitude of the task I had so lightly set Poirot. It would not be easy to secure the acquittal of Jack Renauld, by anything short of the truth. M. Hautet spoke again, with a peculiarly biting inflection: “Madame Renauld told us that this dagger was on her dressing table on the night of the crime. But Madame Renauld is a mother! It will doubtless astonish you, Renauld, but I consider it highly likely that Madame Renauld was mistaken, and that, by inadvertence perhaps, you had taken it with you to Paris. Doubtless you will contradict me ” I saw the lad’s handcuffed hands clench themselves. The perspiration stood out in beads upon his brow, as with a supreme effort he interrupted M. Hautet in a hoarse voice: “I shall not contradict you. It is possible.” It was a stupefying moment. Maître Grosíer rose to his feet, protesting: “My client has undergone a considerable nervous strain. I should wish it put on record that I do not consider him answerable for what he says.” The magistrate quelled him angrily. For a moment a doubt seemed to arise in his own mind. Jack Renauld had almost overdone his part. He leaned forward, and gazed at the prisoner searchingly. “Do you fully understand, Renauld, that on the answers you have given me I shall have no alternative but to commit you for trial?” Jack’s pale face flushed. He looked steadily back. “M. Hautet, I swear that I did not kill my father.” But the magistrate’s brief moment of doubt was over. He laughed a short, unpleasant laugh. “Without doubt, without doubt they are always innocent, our prisoners! By your own mouth you are condemned. You can offer no defence, no alibi only a mere assertion which would not deceive a babe! that you are not guilty. You killed your father, Renauld cruel and cowardly murder for the sake of money which you believed would come to you at his death. Your mother was an accessory after the fact. Doubtless, in view of the fact that she acted as a mother, the courts will extend an indulgence to her that they will not accord to you. And rightly so! Your crime was a horrible one to be held in abhorrence by gods and men!” M. Hautet was enjoying himself, working up his period, steeped in the solemnity of the moment, and his own role as representative of justice. “You killed and you must pay the consequences of your action. I speak to you, not as a man, but as Justice, eternal Justice, which ” M. Hautet was interrupted to his intense annoyance. The door was pushed open. “M. le juge, M. le juge,” stammered the attendant, “there is a lady who says who says ” “Who says what?” cried the justly incensed magistrate. “This is highly irregular. I forbid it I absolutely forbid it.” But a slender figure pushed the stammering gendarme aside. Dressed all in black, with a long veil that hid her face, she advanced into the room. My heart gave a sickening throb. She had come then! All my efforts were in vain. Yet I could not but admire the courage that had led her to take this step so unfalteringly. She raised her veil and I gasped. For, though as like her as two peas, this girl was not Cinderella! On the other hand, now that I saw her without the fair wig she had worn on the stage, I recognized her as the girl of the photograph in Jack Renauld’s room. “You are the Juge d’Instruction, M. Hautet?” she queried. “Yes, but I forbid ” “My name is Bella Duveen. I wish to give myself up for the murder of Mr. Renauld.”

"I remember Joseph Aarons, the theatrical agent. I assisted him with a Japanese wrestler. He can help us find what we need to know. It took time to find him. He agreed to help. Aarons knows a young girl named Bella Duveen. She is a performer. The Dulcibella Kids are her sisters. They are in Coventry at the Palace. Poirot booked tickets for the show. The sisters performed well. Bella Duveen, now Cinderella, confessed to taking the dagger. She feared being caught. I comforted her and confessed my love. She was surprised and asked why I wouldn't turn her in. I reassured her of my love and understanding. She was relieved and asked what I knew."

The furniture and house had finally been sold off, managing to cover our outstanding debts. Despite my efforts, I had yet to secure a job. Truth be told, I wasn't exactly eager to find one! I firmly believed that if I sought out adventure, it would come to me. In my experience, one's desires always come to fruition. And soon enough, my belief was put to the test. It happened on a cold January 8th, right after an unsuccessful meeting with a woman seeking a secretary-companion, though it seemed she really needed a laborer willing to toil twelve hours a day for a measly £25 per year.

“Always stay vigilant for danger,” Mr. Rayburn warned me, his voice filled with urgency. “And remember, if you ever find yourself in their grasp, honesty may be your only salvation.”His words sent a shiver down my spine. “Your caution is unsettling, Mr. Rayburn,” I admitted, my heart racing with unease. “But why go to such lengths to protect me?”Mr. Rayburn fell silent, his expression grave. After a moment, he spoke softly, almost as if to himself: “This may be the final favor I can offer. Once ashore, I will be safe, but reaching land is not guaranteed.”“What do you mean?” I exclaimed, my mind reeling with the implications. “Are you suggesting that my knowledge of your identity as 'The Man in the Brown Suit' puts us both in jeopardy?”

"Informant, I must insist." We had reached the stairs leading to the entrance of the Mansion. Inside, another officer was waiting. When the chief arrived, he asked for the whereabouts of Mr. Hautet. "He's in the living room, sir." Mr. Bex opened a door on the right, and we followed. Mr. Hautet and his assistant were seated at a large rectangular table. They glanced over as we stepped in. The chief introduced us and explained the reason for our visit. Mr. Hautet, the Investigating Judge, was a tall man with sharp eyes and a well-groomed grey beard that he stroked while speaking.

"I’d rather die than be tough,” I declared fervently. We hopped in the car and set off. I gathered myself slowly. Out of the blue, he held my hand. “Anne,” he said softly, “I want you. Will you marry me?” I was shocked. “Oh, no,” I stuttered. “I can’t.” “Why not?” “I don’t have feelings for you in that way. I never saw you like that.” “I understand. Is that the only reason?” I had to be truthful. I owed him that. “No,” I replied, “it's not. I care for someone else.” “I see,” he said again. “And was that true from the start when I first saw you on the Kilmorden?” “No,” I murmured. “It has been since then.” “I see,” he repeated for the third time, but now there was a determined tone in his voice that made me look at him. His face was more serious than ever before. “What do you mean?” I faltered. He looked at me, unreadable, commanding. “Only that I now know what I must do.” His words sent a chill down my spine. There was a resolve in them that I couldn't comprehend and it scared me. Neither of us said another word until we reached the hotel. I went straight to Suzanne. She was lounging on her bed reading and seemed unaffected, not at all like she had a headache. “Here lies the perfect gooseberry,” she joked. “Also known as the tactful chaperone. Why, Anne dear, what's wrong?” I burst into tears. I told her about the cats but felt it wasn't right to tell her about Colonel Race. Suzanne is very perceptive. I think she sensed there was more to it. “You haven't caught a chill, have you, Anne? Sounds ridiculous to suggest such things in this heat, but you keep shivering.” “It's nothing,” I replied. “Just nerves or a feeling that something terrible is about to happen.” “Don't be silly,” Suzanne said firmly. “Let's talk about something interesting. Anne, about those diamonds.” “What about them?” “I'm worried they're not safe with me. It was fine before, no one would have thought they'd be among my things. But now that everyone knows we're such good friends, you and I, I'll be under suspicion too.” “Nobody knows they're in a roll of films, though,” I argued. “It's a great hiding spot and I don't think we could find a better one.” She agreed reluctantly, but said we'd revisit the topic when we got to the Falls. Our train departed at nine o'clock. Sir Eustace was still in a bad mood, and Miss Pettigrew seemed subdued. Colonel Race was his usual self. I felt like I had dreamt the whole conversation on the way back. I slept deeply that night on my hard bunk, battling with vague, menacing dreams. I woke up with a headache and went out to the observation platform of the car. It was cool and beautiful, with rolling wooded hills as far as the eye could see. I adored it, more than any other place I'd been to. I wished I could have a little hut in the heart of the scrub and live there forever. Just before half past two, Colonel Race called me out from the "office" and pointed to a bouquet-shaped white mist hovering over part of the bush. “The spray from the Falls,” he explained. “We're almost there.” I was still wrapped in that strange dream-like feeling of elation that followed my troubled night. I strongly felt that I had come home. Home! And yet I had never been here before or had I in dreams? We walked from the train to the hotel, a large white building protected against mosquitoes. There were no roads, no houses. We stepped out onto the veranda and I gasped. Half a mile away, facing us, were the Falls. I'd never seen anything so magnificent and beautiful, and I never will. “Anne, you're strange,” Suzanne commented as we sat down for lunch. “I've never seen you like this before.” She looked at me curiously. “Am I?” I laughed, but it felt forced. “It's just that I love it all.” “It's more than that.” A slight frown of concern crossed her forehead. Yes, I was happy, but beyond that, I had the odd sensation that I was waiting for something, something that would happen soon. I was excited, restless. After tea, we went out, hopped on the trolley, and were pushed by smiling locals down the rails to the bridge. It was a remarkable sight, the vast chasm and the rushing waters below, the veil of mist and spray in front of us that parted occasionally to reveal the waterfall and then closed up again in its mysterious allure. That, to me, has always been the allure of the Falls—their elusive nature. You always think you're about to see something, but you never do. We crossed the bridge and strolled along the path marked with white stone on either side, leading around the gorge. Finally, we reached a large clearing where a path led downwards towards the chasm. “The palm gully,” explained Colonel Race. “Shall we go down? Or shall we leave it for tomorrow? It's quite a climb up again.” “We'll leave it for tomorrow,” Sir Eustace decided. He's not keen on strenuous physical activities, I've noticed. He led the way back. As we passed, we saw a native followed by a woman carrying an assortment of household items piled on her head, including a frying pan! “I never have my camera when I need it,” moaned Suzanne. “That's an opportunity that will present itself often enough, Mrs. Blair,” Colonel Race assured her. “So don't be upset.” We arrived back on the bridge. “Shall we venture into the rainbow forest?” he asked. “Or are you afraid of getting wet?” Suzanne and I joined him. Sir Eustace went back to the hotel. I found the rainbow forest somewhat disappointing. There weren't enough rainbows, and we ended up soaked, but every now and then, we caught a glimpse of the Falls and realized how incredibly wide they are.

"After identifying the sole doctor in Marsdon Leigh as Dr. Ralph Bernard, we arrived at his residence. Situated slightly off the main road, the house appeared to be a refined cottage. The doctor's name was displayed on a brass plate attached to the gate. As we walked up the path and rang the bell, luck was on our side. We caught Dr. Bernard during his consulting hour, with no patients in queue at that moment. Dr. Bernard, an elderly man with a slight stoop and genial demeanor, welcomed us. Poirot, introducing himself, outlined the purpose of our visit, emphasizing the necessity for Insurance Companies to conduct a thorough investigation in such cases."

A big sedan is parked on the deserted street, looking like it's having mechanical issues. The driver waves for O’Murphy to pull over. As O’Murphy decelerates, the stranger comes closer. Daniels sticks his head out of the window, and, likely using a fast-acting anesthetic like ethyl chloride, executes the chloroform scheme once more. In no time, the two vulnerable men are hauled out and switched to a different vehicle, while two replacements seamlessly take their spots.

I have been taken into custody, mother." "What?" She let out a shrill scream, and before anyone could reach her, she swayed and collapsed heavily. We hurried to her side and raised her up. Shortly after, Poirot got back on his feet. "She has suffered a severe head injury, on the edge of the staircase. I suspect there is also a minor concussion. If Giraud requires a statement from her, he will have to be patient. She will likely be unconscious for at least a week." Denise and Françoise had rushed to their mistress, and with them in charge, Poirot departed from the residence. He walked with his head bowed, furrowing his brow as he pondered the situation. I remained silent for a while, but eventually, I dared to ask him a question. "Do you then believe, despite all evidence to the contrary, that Jack Renauld might be innocent?" Poirot did not respond immediately, but after a long pause, he spoke solemnly: "I am unsure, Hastings. There is a slight possibility. Of course, Giraud is entirely mistaken. If Jack Renauld is guilty, it is not due to Giraud's arguments but in spite of them. And the most serious accusation against him is only known to me." "What is that?" I inquired, intrigued. "If you were to engage your brain cells and see the whole picture as clearly as I do, you would also recognize it, my friend." This was one of Poirot's frustrating replies that I had grown accustomed to. He continued without waiting for my response. "Let us walk towards the sea. We will sit on that small mound there, overlooking the shore, and reassess the situation. You shall be informed of all the details I possess, but I would prefer you to uncover the truth through your own efforts rather than me guiding you every step of the way." We settled on the grassy knoll as Poirot had suggested, gazing out at the sea. The cries of bathers in the distance reached our ears faintly. The ocean was a pale shade of blue, and the tranquil calm reminded me of our arrival at Merlinville, my high spirits, and Poirot's suggestion that I was "fey." It felt like an eternity had passed since then. In reality, it had only been three days. "Concentrate, my friend," Poirot's voice encouraged. "Organize your thoughts. Be methodical. Be systematic. That is the key to success." I tried to follow his advice, recollecting all the intricacies of the case. Reluctantly, it seemed that Giraud's solution, which Poirot dismissed, was the only clear and plausible one. I pondered once more. If there was a glimmer of hope anywhere, it was towards Madame Daubreuil. Giraud was unaware of her involvement in the Beroldy Case. Poirot had emphasized the significance of the Beroldy Case. That was where I needed to focus. I was on the right path now. And suddenly, an astonishingly bright idea flashed into my mind. Shaking, I constructed my theory. "You seem to have a notion, my friend! Excellent. We are making progress." I sat upright and lit a pipe. "Poirot," I began, "it appears that we have been neglectful. I say we, even though I suspect I am more at fault. But you must bear the consequences of your secrecy. So I reiterate, we have overlooked someone." "And who might that be?" Poirot asked, his eyes twinkling. "Georges Conneau!" In the next moment, Poirot embraced me warmly. "Finally! You have reached a conclusion. And all on your own. It is marvelous! Continue your train of thought. You are correct. Undoubtedly, we erred in forgetting Georges Conneau." I was so flattered by the little man's approval that I could barely continue. But eventually, I gathered my thoughts and proceeded. "Georges Conneau vanished twenty years ago, but there is no evidence to suggest that he is deceased." "None at all," Poirot agreed. "Go on." "Therefore, let us assume he is still alive." "Precisely." "Or that he was alive until recently." "Even better!" "Let us suppose," I continued, my excitement growing, "that he has fallen on hard times. He has turned to a life of crime, become an apache, a vagabond, or whatever you wish to call it. By chance, he arrives at Merlinville. There, he encounters the woman he has always loved." "Ah, the sentimentality," cautioned Poirot. "Where there is hatred, there is also love," I quoted or misquoted. "Regardless, he finds her there, living under an assumed name. However, she now has a new lover, the Englishman, Renauld. Georges Conneau, memories of past grievances resurfacing, clashes with Renauld. He ambushes him as he visits his paramour and stabs him in the back. Subsequently, terrified by his actions, he begins to dig a grave. I believe it probable that Madame Daubreuil emerges to search for her lover. She and Conneau engage in a heated argument. He drags her into the shed and suddenly suffers an epileptic seizure. Now, if Jack Renauld were to appear. Madame Daubreuil discloses everything to him, highlighting the dire consequences for her daughter if this old scandal is revived. His father's killer is deceased; they should strive to keep it under wraps. Jack Renauld agrees, proceeds to the house, and converses with his mother, persuading her to see his perspective. Armed with the narrative that Madame Daubreuil has proposed, she consents to be silenced and restrained. So, Poirot, what are your thoughts on this?" I reclined, flushed with the satisfaction of my reconstructed scenario. Poirot regarded me thoughtfully. "I believe you should write for the Kinema, my friend," he remarked finally. "You mean?" "It would make a compelling film, the tale you have recounted to me, but it bears no resemblance to reality." "I admit I have not delved into all the specifics, but " "You have gone beyond that you have sidestepped them admirably. What about the attire of the two men? Are you proposing that after stabbing his victim, Conneau removed his suit, donned it himself, and replaced the dagger?" "I fail to see the relevance," I objected somewhat petulantly. "He might have coerced clothes and money from Madame Daubreuil earlier in the day." "Through coercion, you say? You genuinely put forward that theory?" "Certainly. He could have threatened to expose her identity to the Renaulds, potentially ruining any chance of her daughter's marriage." "You are mistaken, Hastings.

Blair was obsessed with capturing unique photographs as we journeyed higher and higher up the mountain. She insisted on snapping shots of the train's front from the back, claiming it would look dangerously thrilling against the mountain backdrop. Anne Beddingfeld expressed relief at traveling during daylight, marveling at the magnificent scenery. Colonel Race informed her that they only had three trains a week to Rhodesia, leading to a discussion about their plans at the Falls and Johannesburg. Race's assurance about the safety of Jo'burg prompted a skeptical response from Sir Eustace, who suspected Race had ulterior motives involving Anne. The dynamic between the characters hinted at underlying tensions and unspoken desires.

"Did Renauld prevent Madame Daubreuil from leaving? Had she departed already?" "Yes, sir. I overheard them exiting the study and heading towards the door. Monsieur bid her good night and closed the door behind her." "At what time did this occur?" "Around twenty-five minutes past ten, sir." "Do you know when M. Renauld retired to bed?" "I heard him ascending the stairs about ten minutes after us. The stairs creak so loudly that one can hear every step taken." "And is that all? Did you hear any commotion during the night?" "Absolutely nothing, sir." "Who was the first servant to come downstairs in the morning?" "That would be me, sir."

Upon reflection, Havering's encounter with the mysterious figure could be crucial to cracking the case. With her keen eye for detail, she might have observed something pivotal. I promptly penned a detailed letter to Poirot, elaborating on the situation. Additional pieces of evidence were included before I dispatched the correspondence. The bullet recovered matched a revolver in police possession. Moreover, Mr. Havering's alibi was corroborated, confirming his presence in London on the fateful night.

"The small grey matter always remembers the small grey matter, my friend!" I settled into my chair, responding casually to Poirot's greeting by mentioning that a one-hour sea journey from Calais to Dover could hardly be considered "terrible." Poirot vigorously disagreed, waving his egg-spoon to emphasize his point. "Not at all! If in one hour one endures sensations and emotions of the utmost terror, one has truly lived! Does not one of your English poets suggest that time is measured not by hours, but by heartbeats?" "I believe Browning was alluding to something more romantic than seasickness, however." "Because he was an Englishman, an islander for whom the English Channel meant nothing."

I made sure to thoroughly search the girl's belongings upon her arrival. "Where did you suddenly pull that from? It wasn't there a moment ago," I questioned. "Actually, it was," she responded calmly. "I had it hidden in my stocking." Sir Eustace lamented his lack of knowledge about women, admitting, "I should have paid more attention to them." Harry's patience wore thin as he slammed his hand on the table. "Stop the nonsense. If it weren't for your age, I'd toss you out the window, you scoundrel! Age or no age," he growled, taking a few steps forward while Sir Eustace quickly retreated behind the table.

“We gratefully accepted her offer of something to eat, hoping our presence might distract her from her grief. Just as we finished our soup, a scream and the sound of breaking crockery startled us. The parlourmaid rushed in, her hand clutching her heart. “There was a man in the passage,” she gasped. Poirot quickly investigated, but found no one there. “Are you sure?” the maid whispered weakly. “It truly gave me a fright!” “But why?” Poirot inquired, lowering his voice.

"You're certain of that?" "Yes." "No small disagreements, right?" Jack simply shrugged. "Everyone's entitled to their own opinion." "Of course, of course. But if someone were to claim that you had a heated argument with your father before leaving for Paris, that person would be lying, correct?" I couldn't help but admire Giraud's cleverness. His claim that "I know everything" was no joke. Jack Renauld seemed uneasy at the question. "We did argue," he confessed. "Ah, an argument! And during that argument, did you say: 'When you're dead, I can do what I want'?" "I might have," Jack muttered.

"I was just starting to relax when Suzanne abruptly asked: “What's the opposite?” “The opposite of what?” I replied. “There has to be an opposite. What's the term for skulls that are more than 75% as wide as they are long?” “Brachycephalic,” I reluctantly admitted. “Ah, that's right. I thought I heard you say that.” “Did I? Must have misspoke. I meant dolichocephalic,” I confidently stated. Suzanne stared at me intently. Then she burst out laughing. “You're a good liar, Gipsy girl. But let's cut to the chase, tell me everything now to save time and trouble.”

"They're not the hands of a gentleman," he stated, in response to my gaze. "In fact, his attire suggests he's a man of means. Quite intriguing, wouldn't you say?" "Intriguing indeed," I concurred. "And there's no identifiable markings on any of his clothes. What can we deduce from that? This individual was attempting to present himself as someone else. He was pretending. But why? Was he running from something? Was he trying to evade capture by assuming a different persona? At this point, we can only speculate. However, one thing is certain - he was just as determined to hide his true self as we are to uncover it."

Pagett always seems to be one step ahead of everyone else. As I leisurely settled into my deck-chair next to Mrs. Blair, I couldn't help but comment on the state of the clergy in modern times. Casually, I extended an invitation to Mrs. Blair to join me for dinner on the evening of the upcoming Fancy Dress dance, a proposition that Race somehow finagled his way into as well. Following lunch, the Beddingfeld girl joined us for coffee, confirming my previous observation about the exceptional quality of her legs. Without a doubt, I will be extending an invitation to her for dinner too.

"I will inform the authorities." Poirot made his way down the steps. "No, please don't do that!" The man ran after him. Poirot swiftly pushed him down the steps. Within moments, all three of us were safely inside, the door bolted shut. "Quick, in here." Poirot led us into the nearest room, turning on the light. "And you, hide behind the curtain." "Yes, sir," said the Italian, disappearing behind the rose-coloured velvet drapes. Just in time, as a woman rushed in, tall with red hair, clutching a scarlet kimono. "Where is my husband?" she demanded, looking around frantically. Poirot stepped forward gracefully. "I hope your husband won't catch a cold. I noticed he was wearing slippers and a warm dressing-gown." "Who are you? What are you doing here?" "It's unfortunate that we haven't had the pleasure of meeting, madame. One of us came all the way from New York just to see you." The Italian emerged from the curtains, holding my revolver. The woman screamed and tried to run, but Poirot blocked the door. "Let me pass," she cried. "He'll kill me." "Who killed Luigi Valdarno?" asked the Italian, pointing the gun at us. We stood frozen. "Poirot, this is terrible. What do we do?" I asked anxiously. "Please, Hastings, try to stay quiet. I assure you, our friend won't shoot without my signal," Poirot replied calmly. "Are you sure about that?" sneered the Italian. The woman turned to Poirot. "What do you want?" Poirot bowed. "I don't think I need to explain things to Miss Elsa Hardt." The woman grabbed a black velvet cat covering the telephone. "They're hidden in here." "Impressive," Poirot commented. He stepped aside. "Goodbye, madame. I'll keep your friend occupied while you make your escape." "You fool!" the Italian shouted, aiming the gun at the woman. I lunged at him, but the gun clicked harmlessly. Poirot shook his head. "You shouldn't carry loaded pistols, my friend. I wouldn't allow an acquaintance to do so either." The Italian swore as Poirot continued to address him sternly. "I saved you from a noose. The police are waiting outside. You can leave now, but be cautious. Ah, he's gone! Hastings, you look at me with reproach. It was all so clear! Out of hundreds of applicants for No. 4, Montagu Mansions, only the Robinsons were chosen. Why? What made them stand out? Their name, perhaps!" "But Robinson is a common name," I objected. "Exactly! That's the point. Elsa Hardt and her companion took the flat under the name Mr. and Mrs. Robinson. When they realized they were being hunted by a secret society, they devised a plan. They knew their pursuers didn't know them personally. So they offered the flat at a low price, waiting for a fair-haired Mrs. Robinson to show up. And when she did, the avenger struck. Vengeance satisfied, and Elsa Hardt escaped once more. We must hurry back. I hear Japp and his team arriving." The door knocker sounded loudly. "How did you find this address?" I asked as we left. "You had the first Mrs. Robinson followed," Poirot explained. "Well done, Hastings. Now, let's give Japp a surprise."

Poirot and I hurried to Saint-Omer to meet M. Hautet, the examining magistrate. We were ushered into his room, where he expressed his relief that Poirot had not actually returned to England. M. Hautet lamented the skill of Giraud, the detective, and his certainty of Jack Renauld's guilt. Poirot, however, remained unconvinced, citing various obscure points in the case. When asked about Jack's defense, M. Hautet revealed his frustration with Jack's silence during questioning. The magistrate also shared concerns about Madame Renauld's fragile mental state after the tragic events. As the conversation turned to a letter for Poirot, I couldn't shake the feeling of impending doom.

When he dared to challenge Fate, he proved to be a skilled player. He could face defeat with a grin. "Regardless," he remarked casually, "I doubt our paths will cross again." "No," I responded slowly. "I don't think so." "Farewell then." "Farewell." He squeezed my hand tightly, his unusual gleaming eyes locking with mine for a moment, then he abruptly departed, his footsteps resonating along the ship's deck. The sound reverberated in my ears. Footsteps exiting my world. I must confess, the following couple of hours were far from pleasant.

I wonder about this Chichester character who seems so innocent. Perhaps Pagett will have some insight. He always seems to know everything. The evening was quite eventful, with Mrs. Blair's refusal to dress up and Race's sudden chattiness after some champagne. I danced with various ladies, including Anne Beddingfeld, who looked stunning in her gipsy costume. As the night went on, I shared some entertaining lion stories, much to the amusement of the guests. It was a delightful evening, despite Pagett's absence and Reeves' presence. The South African Labour party member might come in handy for some information I seek. Overall, it was a night full of surprises and laughter.

Mr. Poirot and I were waiting in the hotel room of the Opalsens. Mrs. Opalsen was weeping, her pearls missing. Mr. Opalsen paced angrily, while two police officials stood by. The chambermaid and the French maid were also present, both in distress. Mrs. Opalsen believed in luck, convinced that Poirot was the one to find her pearls. Poirot reassured her, promising to help. Mrs. Opalsen then recounted how she found her jewel-case empty after dinner, despite the room being locked and her maid present. The inspector suggested a duplicate key was used. Célestine, the maid, was horrified at the implication and turned to Poirot for help, disregarding the police's incompetence.

"Suzanne, in her matrimonial situation, longed for a man to lean on. Nevertheless, she vowed not to disclose anything to Colonel Race and we proceeded with our strategizing. ‘It is evident that I must remain here and monitor Pagett, and this is the most effective approach. I must make it seem like I am leaving for Durban tonight, pack my belongings and so forth, but in reality, I will check into a small hotel in town. I can modify my appearance slightly, wear a blonde toupee and a thick white lace veil, and I will have a better chance of uncovering his true motives if he believes I am safely out of the picture.’ Suzanne wholeheartedly endorsed this plan. We carried out elaborate and ostentatious arrangements, confirming the train departure time at the office and preparing my luggage. We had dinner together at the restaurant. Colonel Race was absent, but Sir Eustace and Pagett were seated at their table by the window. Pagett left halfway through the meal, which irked me as I had intended to bid him farewell. Nevertheless, Sir Eustace would suffice. After finishing my meal, I approached him. ‘Farewell, Sir Eustace,’ I uttered. ‘I am departing for Durban tonight.’ Sir Eustace let out a heavy sigh. ‘So I heard. Would you like me to accompany you?’ ‘I would appreciate it.’ ‘Lovely girl. Are you absolutely certain you won’t reconsider and come to search for lions in Rhodesia?’ ‘Absolutely sure.’ ‘He must be quite a handsome chap,’ Sir Eustace remarked plaintively. ‘Some young upstart in Durban, I presume, who outshines my mature charms completely. By the way, Pagett will be going down in the car shortly. He could drop you off at the station.’ ‘Oh, no, thank you,’ I hastily declined. ‘Mrs. Blair and I have arranged for our own taxi.’ The last thing I wanted was to travel with Guy Pagett! Sir Eustace scrutinized me intently. ‘I don’t believe you fancy Pagett. I don’t blame you. Of all the overbearing, meddlesome fools parading around with a martyr-like demeanor, doing everything in their power to irritate and unsettle me!’ ‘What has he done now?’ I asked, somewhat intrigued. ‘He’s hired a secretary for me. You’ve never seen such a woman! At least forty years old, wears pince-nez and sensible shoes, and exudes an air of brisk efficiency that may be the end of me. A true stern-faced woman.’ ‘Will she be overly familiar with you?’ ‘I fervently hope not!’ exclaimed Sir Eustace. ‘That would be the final straw. Well, goodbye, enchanting eyes. If I happen to bag a lion, I won’t give you the pelt after the treacherous manner in which you’ve abandoned me.’ He warmly squeezed my hand and we parted ways. Suzanne awaited me in the lobby. She was to see me off. ‘Let’s depart immediately,’ I urged, signaling to the man to summon a taxi. Suddenly, a voice behind me caused me to start: ‘Pardon me, Miss Beddingfeld, but I’m about to head down in a car. I can drop you and Mrs. Blair at the station.’ ‘Oh, thank you,’ I hurriedly replied. ‘But there’s no need to inconvenience you. I’ ‘No inconvenience at all, I assure you. Load the luggage, porter.’ I was powerless. I could have continued to object, but a subtle warning nudge from Suzanne encouraged me to be cautious. ‘Thank you, Mr. Pagett,’ I coldly acknowledged. We all entered the car. As we sped down the road towards town, I searched my mind for something to say. Eventually, Pagett broke the silence himself. ‘I have procured a highly competent secretary for Sir Eustace,’ he remarked. ‘Miss Pettigrew.’ ‘He wasn’t exactly singing her praises earlier,’ I commented. Pagett shot me a cold glance. ‘She is a skilled shorthand typist,’ he replied sternly. We pulled up in front of the station. Surely here he would bid us farewell. I turned with my hand outstretched but no. ‘I will accompany you to see you off. It’s precisely eight o’clock, your train departs in fifteen minutes.’ He efficiently directed the porters. I stood helplessly, refraining from glancing at Suzanne. The man was suspicious. He was intent on ensuring that I indeed boarded the train. And what could I do? Nothing. I envisioned myself, in fifteen minutes’ time, departing from the station with Pagett stationed on the platform bidding me adieu. He had skillfully turned the tables on me. Furthermore, his demeanor towards me had shifted. It was marked by an uneasy affability that did not suit him and repulsed me. The man was a deceitful hypocrite. First, he attempted to murder me, and now he was paying me compliments! Did he honestly think I hadn’t recognized him that night on the boat? No, it was a facade, a facade to which he compelled me to consent, all the while being sly about it. Helpless as a lamb, I obeyed his expert directions. My luggage was stowed in my sleeping compartment, which I had entirely to myself. It was twelve minutes past eight. The train would depart in three minutes. However, Pagett had not accounted for Suzanne. ‘The journey will be dreadfully warm, Anne,’ she suddenly remarked. ‘Especially when passing through the Karoo tomorrow. Do you have any eau-de-Cologne or lavender water with you?’ My cue was clear. ‘Oh, dear,’ I exclaimed. ‘I left my eau-de-Cologne on the dressing table at the hotel.’ Suzanne’s commanding nature served her well. She imperiously turned to Pagett. ‘Mr. Pagett. Quick. You have just enough time. There’s a chemist nearly opposite the station. Anne must procure some eau-de-Cologne.’ He hesitated, but Suzanne’s authoritative tone left him with little choice. She was a born leader. He departed. Suzanne followed him with her gaze until he vanished. ‘Hurry, Anne, exit on the other side in case he has not truly departed but is observing us from the end of the platform. Forget your luggage. You can address that tomorrow via telegram."

“Anne,” Suzanne whispered urgently, glancing around anxiously for eavesdroppers. “A distinctly good idea,” Anne approved, nodding. Suzanne explained how the big cases were sent to Cape Town and the small ones were likely with Sir Eustace. Anne decided to wait until further action was necessary. The next day, she planned to meet Guy Pagett to find out more. Anne received instructions to go to Johannesburg urgently. Anne listened to Pagett’s story about his trip to Marlow, trying to understand his mysterious behavior. Pagett revealed a surprising secret about his past, leaving Anne shocked. Anne pondered her next move carefully.

Not so Poirot. Dressed precisely the same as in London, he carried a small clothes-brush in his pocket and waged an unceasing war on the dust which accumulated on his dark apparel. “And my boots,” he wailed. “Regard them, Hastings. My boots, of the neat patent leather, usually so smart and shining. See, the sand is inside them, which is painful, and outside them, which outrages the eyesight. Also the heat, it causes my moustaches to become limp but limp!” “Look at the Sphinx,” I urged. “Even I can feel the mystery and the charm it exhales.” Poirot looked at it discontentedly. “It has not the air happy,” he declared. “How could it, half-buried in sand in that untidy fashion. Ah, this cursed sand!” “Come, now, there’s a lot of sand in Belgium,” I reminded him, mindful of a holiday spent at Knocke-sur-mer in the midst of “les dunes impeccables” as the guide-book had phrased it. “Not in Brussels,” declared Poirot. He gazed at the Pyramids thoughtfully. “It is true that they, at least, are of a shape solid and geometrical, but their surface is of an unevenness most unpleasing. And the palm-trees I like them not. Not even do they plant them in rows!” I cut short his lamentations, by suggesting that we should start for the camp. We were to ride there on camels, and the beasts were patiently kneeling, waiting for us to mount, in charge of several picturesque boys headed by a voluble dragoman. I pass over the spectacle of Poirot on a camel. He started by groans and lamentations and ended by shrieks, gesticulations and invocations to the Virgin Mary and every Saint in the calendar. In the end, he descended ignominiously and finished the journey on a diminutive donkey. I must admit that a trotting camel is no joke for the amateur. I was stiff for several days. At last we neared the scene of the excavations. A sunburnt man with a grey beard, in white clothes and wearing a helmet, came to meet us. “Monsieur Poirot and Captain Hastings? We received your cable. I’m sorry that there was no one to meet you in Cairo. An unforeseen event occurred which completely disorganized our plans.” Poirot paled. His hand, which had stolen to his clothes-brush, stayed its course. “Not another death?” he breathed. “Yes.” “Sir Guy Willard?” I cried. “No, Captain Hastings. My American colleague, Mr. Schneider.” “And the cause?” demanded Poirot. “Tetanus.” I blanched. All around me I seemed to feel an atmosphere of evil, subtle and menacing. A horrible thought flashed across me. Supposing I were the next? “Mon Dieu,” said Poirot, in a very low voice, “I do not understand this. It is horrible. Tell me, monsieur, there is no doubt that it was tetanus?” “I believe not. But Dr. Ames will tell you more than I can do.” “Ah, of course, you are not the doctor.” “My name is Tosswill.” This, then, was the British expert described by Lady Willard as being a minor official at the British Museum. There was something at once grave and steadfast about him that took my fancy. “If you will come with me,” continued Dr. Tosswill, “I will take you to Sir Guy Willard. He was most anxious to be informed as soon as you should arrive.” We were taken across the camp to a large tent. Dr. Tosswill lifted up the flap and we entered. Three men were sitting inside. “Monsieur Poirot and Captain Hastings have arrived, Sir Guy,” said Tosswill. The youngest of the three men jumped up and came forward to greet us. There was a certain impulsiveness in his manner which reminded me of his mother. He was not nearly so sunburnt as the others, and that fact, coupled with a certain haggardness round the eyes, made him look older than his twenty-two years. He was clearly endeavouring to bear up under a severe mental strain. He introduced his two companions, Dr. Ames, a capable looking man of thirty odd, with a touch of greying hair at the temples, and Mr. Harper, the secretary, a pleasant lean young man wearing the national insignia of horn-rimmed spectacles. After a few minutes’ desultory conversation the latter went out, and Dr. Tosswill followed him. We were left alone with Sir Guy and Dr. Ames. “Please ask any questions you want to ask, Monsieur Poirot,” said Willard. “We are utterly dumbfounded at this strange series of disasters, but it isn’t it can’t be, anything but coincidence.” There was a nervousness about his manner which rather belied the words. I saw that Poirot was studying him keenly. “Your heart is really in this work, Sir Guy?” “Rather. No matter what happens, or what comes of it, the work is going on. Make up your mind to that.” Poirot wheeled round on the other. “What have you to say to that, monsieur le docteur?” “Well,” drawled the doctor, “I’m not for quitting myself.” Poirot made one of those expressive grimaces of his. “Then, évidemment, we must find out just how we stand. When did Mr. Schneider’s death take place?” “Three days ago.” “You are sure it was tetanus?” “Dead sure.” “It couldn’t have been a case of strychnine poisoning, for instance?” “No, Monsieur Poirot. I see what you’re getting at. But it was a clear case of tetanus.” “Did you not inject anti-serum?” “Certainly we did,” said the doctor dryly. “Every conceivable thing that could be done was tried.” “Had you the anti-serum with you?” “No. We procured it from Cairo.” “Have there been any other cases of tetanus in the camp?” “No, not one.” “Are you certain that the death of Mr. Bleibner was not due to tetanus?” “Absolutely plumb certain. He had a scratch upon his thumb which became poisoned, and septicæmia set in. It sounds pretty much the same to a layman, I dare say, but the two things are entirely different.” “Then we have four deaths all totally dissimilar, one heart failure, one blood poisoning, one suicide and one tetanus.” “Exactly, Monsieur Poirot.” “Are you certain that there is nothing which might link the four together?” “I don’t quite understand you?” “I will put it plainly.

As I entered the dimly lit room, the moonlight cast eerie shadows across the floor. The wooden floorboards creaked beneath my weight as I cautiously made my way further inside. Suddenly, a faint whisper reached my ears, causing me to freeze in place. Time seemed to stand still as I hesitated, contemplating the potential dangers that lay ahead. Despite the risks, my insatiable curiosity drove me forward. Taking a deep breath, I steeled myself and pressed on, determined to uncover the secrets hidden within the walls of the mysterious house.

"You know, I have feelings for someone else," I admitted. His response was a simple, "I understand." I hesitated before confessing, "It didn't start out that way when we met on the Kilmorden." His next words carried a weight I had never felt before, "I see." His expression was stern, a stark contrast to his usual demeanor. "What are you trying to say?" I asked, my voice wavering. His gaze was intense, commanding. "I now know what needs to be done," he declared. His declaration sent a chill down my spine, his resolve both mysterious and unsettling.

"I have some questions for you tomorrow, and once you answer, we will know how to proceed. We have ways to make stubborn people talk," he said sternly. Despite the grim situation, I was relieved to have until the following day. This man seemed to be following orders from someone higher up. Could it be Pagett? He called for two Kafirs, who escorted me upstairs. Despite my efforts to resist, I was quickly gagged and bound. The room they brought me to was an attic, dusty and seemingly unused.

As we embarked on our journey, I couldn't contain my excitement. The fresh air filled me with joy and anticipation for the trip ahead. Despite my cheerful outlook, my companion reminded me of the impending task awaiting us at our destination. I waved off his concerns, confident in his ability to unravel the mysteries that lay ahead. With Hercule Poirot by my side, success was surely within reach. But as I teased him about his renowned skills, he simply gazed at me solemnly, sensing something amiss. It seemed as though he saw through my facade, recognizing a sense of foreboding lurking beneath my optimistic demeanor.

"And the nephew? What do you know of his tastes? Was he with the party at all?” “I do not think so. In fact I never knew of his existence till I read of his death in the paper, I do not think he and Mr. Bleibner can have been at all intimate. He never spoke of having any relations.” “Who are the other members of the party?” “Well, there is Dr. Tosswill, a minor official connected with the British Museum; Mr. Schneider of the Metropolitan Museum in New York; a young American secretary; Dr. Johnson, a renowned archaeologist specializing in ancient civilizations."

Man is a creature of habit. Habitual in his lawful routines, just as predictable in his unlawful activities. When a man breaks the law, his subsequent transgressions tend to mirror the original offense. Take for instance the notorious English killer who eliminated his spouses one after the other by drowning them in their own tubs. If he had only diversified his tactics, perhaps he could have evaded capture indefinitely. However, he fell victim to the conventional patterns of human behavior, convinced that past methods would guarantee future success. And so, he ultimately suffered the consequences of his unimaginative approach.

"Ah, we have it! 'Yardly, 10th viscount, fought in South African War' none of that matters 'married in 1907 to Hon. Maude Stopperton, daughter of 3rd Baron Cotteril' um, um, um, 'two daughters born in 1908, 1910. Clubs residences.' Well, that doesn't reveal much. But tomorrow morning we meet this nobleman!" "What?" "Yes. I sent a telegram to him." "I thought you were done with the case?" "I no longer represent Miss Marvell since she won't follow my advice. What I do now is for my own satisfaction and the satisfaction of Hercule Poirot! Clearly, I need to be involved in this matter."

Poirot suspected that the Robinsons were actually Elsa Hardt and her accomplice, using a common name to evade detection. The plan was to lure in their pursuers by offering a flat to a Mrs. Robinson. When the real Mrs. Robinson arrived, they would strike. Poirot, Hastings, and the Italian accomplice managed to capture Elsa Hardt, who revealed the location of the hidden goods. The American Secret Service agent, Mr. Burt, assisted in the arrest. Poirot, recovering from influenza, was ready to resume his detective work. Roger Havering urgently requested Poirot's presence in Derbyshire.

I was in the middle of a conversation with him about the shocking events of that day - the failed assassination attempt on Mr. David MacAdam, the Prime Minister of England. The newspapers had little information, only mentioning that the Prime Minister narrowly avoided the bullet. It was clear that our law enforcement had been negligent for such a serious incident to occur. I couldn't help but think that German spies operating in England would go to great lengths to pull off such a bold move.

"If O’Murphy is truly an honest man, what compelled him to veer off the main road? Conversely, if he was a man of deceit, what motivated him to restart the vehicle after only two shots rang out, quite possibly averting the Prime Minister’s demise? Moreover, if he was indeed honorable, why did he promptly head to a notorious haunt of German intelligence operatives upon departing Charing Cross?” “The situation appears rather dubious,” I remarked. “Let us approach this matter systematically. What evidence do we possess regarding these individuals? Let us begin with O’Murphy."

"I've made a reappearance," I informed him gravely. "How's everything, Mr. Pagett?" "All good, looking forward to getting back to work with Sir Eustace," he replied. "There's something I need to ask you," I began cautiously. "It's crucial, more than you realize. What were you doing in Marlow on January 8th?" His reaction was immediate. "Miss Beddingfeld, I..." "You were there, right?" "I had my reasons for being in the area," he admitted. "Care to share those reasons with me?" "Hasn't Sir Eustace already filled you in?" "Sir Eustace? Does he know?" "I'm pretty sure he does."

"Tell me, what has caught your interest?" I asked confidently, although half-expecting him to mock my suspicions. To my astonishment, he nodded in agreement. "You are correct, Hastings. I have always had a feeling that she was withholding something. Initially, I had my doubts about her, suspecting her involvement, if not direct, then at least indirect." "You suspected her?" I exclaimed. "Absolutely! She stands to gain significantly from this new will, being the sole beneficiary. Therefore, she was immediately under my scrutiny. You might have noticed that I made a point of inspecting her wrists early on."

"We were unceremoniously escorted out. 'I am not satisfied,' Poirot murmured, stepping onto the sidewalk. 'Were you hoping for more revelations? Those old codgers are not exactly a thrilling bunch.' 'It's not their lack of excitement that bothers me, my friend. I am not anticipating a Bank manager to embody a 'sharp-eyed financial wizard' as your beloved novels portray. No, I am let down by the simplicity of the case!' 'Simple?' 'Indeed, isn't it almost laughably easy?' 'You already know who took the bonds?' 'I do.' 'Then why must we...?' 'Don't get ahead of yourself, Hastings. We are to remain idle for now."

Chichester and Mr. Pagett. "You will let me have it, won’t you?” I always say that sailors are the nicest to women. My purser came to the rescue magnificently. He confidently approached, clarified that No. 17 was my cabin, and offered them Nos. 13 and 28 or the option to stay put. I expressed my gratitude with a glance and settled into my new quarters. The incident lifted my spirits. The sea was calm, the temperature rising. Seasickness was a thing of the past! I ventured onto the deck and learned the game of deck-quoits. I signed up for various sports events.

“Hastings, what was Jack Renauld doing here on that fateful night, and if not Marthe, then who did he see?” “Poirot, you can’t possibly think a young man like him would kill his own father,” I exclaimed. “My friend, your naivety is astonishing! I have witnessed mothers who have slain their own children for money. After that, nothing surprises me.” “And the reason?” “Greed, as always. Jack believed he would inherit half of his father’s wealth upon his demise.” “But what about the vagrant?”

"He might have had," I answered thoughtfully, recalling our discussion after returning from the Matoppos. "He’s a very powerful personality," I continued, "but not at all my idea of the 'Colonel.' And, in any case, the notion is preposterous. He’s with the Secret Service." "But how can we be sure of that? It’s so easy to insinuate such things. No one refutes it, and the gossip spreads until it's accepted as absolute truth. It justifies all sorts of questionable actions. Anne, what’s your opinion on Race?" "I have mixed feelings," I replied.

“Kids these days are always looking for trouble,” he remarked disdainfully. “They don't think before they act, just relying on their strength. Let's be rational here. Right now you may have the advantage, but that won't last. My men are all over this house. You don't stand a chance. Your temporary control is just luck.” “Oh really?” Harry's tone of voice caught Sir Eustace's attention, a hint of dark humor in his words. Sir Eustace peered at him. “Really?” Harry repeated. “Take a seat, Sir Eustace, and hear me out.” Keeping his gun pointed at him, he continued, “Luck is not on your side this time. First off, listen to that!” A muffled thud could be heard from the door below.

"I don't want to point fingers, but the murder did take place in Sir Eustace's home," Anne said. Suzanne replied, "I'll keep an eye on him for you, Anne. If he starts looking any plumper and happier, I'll send you a telegram right away. 'Sir E. expanding. Very suspicious. Immediate action required.'"Anne protested, "Suzanne, this is not a game!"Suzanne shrugged, "To me, it is. Blame yourself, Anne. Your sense of adventure has rubbed off on me. It all feels so unreal."

I noticed that the cupboard appeared empty at first, but my persistence paid off when I discovered a hard paper cylinder hidden in a trough in the corner. Upon grabbing it, I immediately recognized it as a roll of Kodak films. This was a valuable discovery! While I considered the possibility that the films belonged to Sir Eustace Pedler and had been overlooked during the cupboard's previous search, the red paper seemed too new for that to be the case.

"Eight years he's been by my side, a loyal companion indeed," my acquaintance grinned. "But we seem to be talking past each other. I'm talking about the woman." "Miss Pettigrew?" I gasped. "Yes. Reports have her exiting Agrasato’s Native Curio-shop," he disclosed. "Good Lord!" I interjected. "I was heading there myself this very afternoon. You could have easily caught me leaving!" It seems in Jo'burg, no innocent action goes unquestioned. "But she's been spotted there multiple times, always under questionable circumstances."

I arrived at the edge of the cliff, overlooking the vast ocean below, far from any signs of civilization. A young boy with a friendly smile greeted me at the door. "Are you here to see Mrs. Raffini?" he asked. Leading me through a narrow hallway, he opened a door for me. As I prepared to enter, a feeling of unease washed over me. Ignoring my instincts, I crossed the threshold and the door closed abruptly behind me. A man stood up from his desk, approaching me with a welcoming smile. "We are delighted you decided to join us, Miss Thompson," he said.

"I'll challenge you to a game of quoits tomorrow," he declared. I remained silent. "Do you think you'll never bounce back? I've seen others in worse shape than you, and within two days they were the life of the party. You'll see." I wasn't in the mood to flat out call him a liar. I tried to convey it through a look. After a few more minutes of pleasant conversation, he thankfully left. Couples walked by, children played, and young people laughed. A few other pale patients, like myself, reclined in deck chairs. The air was refreshing, cool but not too cold, and the sun shone brightly.

“I see that you work independently as a private detective,” Mr. Vavasour stated. “Indeed, we have involved Scotland Yard in this matter. Inspector McNeil is leading the investigation. A competent officer, I must say.” Poirot nodded politely. “May I ask a few questions on behalf of your nephew? Who ordered the lock from Hubbs's?” Mr. Shaw replied, “I personally ordered it. I did not entrust this task to any clerk. Mr. Ridgeway had one key, while my colleague and I held the other two.” “Have any clerks had access to the keys?” Mr. Shaw looked at Mr. Vavasour for confirmation. “To my knowledge, the keys have remained in the safe since we placed them there on the 23rd,” Mr. Vavasour replied. “My colleague fell ill a fortnight ago, the same day Philip departed. He has only recently recovered.” “Severe bronchitis is no laughing matter for a man of my age,” Mr. Shaw remarked. “But Mr. Vavasour has had to bear the brunt of the workload in my absence, especially with this unforeseen problem arising.” Poirot proceeded with a series of inquiries, attempting to assess the relationship between uncle and nephew. Mr. Vavasour's responses were concise and precise. His nephew, a trusted employee of the Bank, had no known debts or financial troubles. He had been assigned similar tasks in the past. Eventually, we were politely excused. “I am underwhelmed,” Poirot commented as we left the premises. “You were hoping to uncover more?
