I mentally listed the individuals I needed to keep an eye on. Excluding the mysterious visitor from the night before, whom I was determined to identify before the day was out, I identified the following people as deserving of my attention. (1) Sir Eustace Pedler, the owner of the Mill House, whose presence on the Kilmorden Castle struck me as more than just a coincidence. (2) Mr. Pagett, the secretary with a sinister air, whose strong desire for Cabin 17 had not gone unnoticed. Note: Verify whether he had traveled to Cannes with Sir Eustace. (3) The Rev. Edward Chichester. My only qualm against him was his stubbornness about Cabin 17, which could simply be a reflection of his own personality. Stubbornness can be a curious trait. However, I deemed it necessary to have a chat with Mr. Chichester. Quickly tying a handkerchief around my unruly hair, I returned to the deck with determination. Luck was on my side. My target was standing by the rail, sipping beef tea. I approached him. "I trust you've forgiven me regarding Cabin 17," I said, mustering my friendliest smile. "It goes against my beliefs to hold a grudge," Mr. Chichester replied coldly. "But the purser had assured me that cabin." "Pursers are always occupied, aren't they?" I replied vaguely. "I suppose they're bound to forget every now and then."

"The possession of Cabin 17 seems to be a matter of contention," I remarked casually. Pagett, with a look of concern, proceeded to reveal a mysterious encounter involving Mr. Chichester and Miss Beddingfeld. Despite my attempts to downplay the situation, Pagett persisted in his suspicions, insinuating foul play. His paranoia extended to the presence of Colonel Race, a Secret Service agent on board. As Pagett spun his tales of intrigue and danger, I couldn't help but find amusement in his dramatic nature. It was clear that the journey ahead was bound to be filled with unexpected twists and turns.

"I couldn't help but chuckle at Poirot's perspective on the case, and my dear friend smiled warmly at me, holding no grudge. He inquired, “But M. Renauld, he played golf, didn't he?” “Yes, he was an avid golfer. Thanks to him and his generous donations, this project is moving forward. He even had a hand in its design.” Poirot nodded thoughtfully. Then he noted, “They didn't choose a good spot to bury the body, did they? Once the ground was dug up, everything would have been revealed.” “Exactly,” Giraud exclaimed triumphantly. “That proves they were unfamiliar with the area. It's a strong piece of indirect evidence.” “Yes,” Poirot said hesitantly. “No one familiar with the place would bury a body there unless they wanted it to be discovered. And that's clearly ridiculous, isn't it?” Giraud didn't bother to respond. “Yes,” Poirot added, sounding somewhat dissatisfied. “Yes, undoubtedly absurd!” As we headed back to the house, M. Bex excused himself to inform the examining magistrate of Giraud's arrival. Giraud seemed pleased when Poirot indicated he had seen everything he needed. The last thing we saw as we left was Giraud meticulously searching on all fours, a sight that impressed me. Poirot seemed to grasp my thoughts, as he remarked sarcastically when we were alone, “Finally, you've seen the detective you admire, the human bloodhound! Isn't that right, my friend?” “At least he's taking action,” I retorted. “If there's something to find, he'll find it. What about you?” “Well, I've found something too! A piece of lead piping.” “Ridiculous, Poirot. You know perfectly well that's irrelevant. I meant small details, traces that could lead us directly to the culprits.” “My friend, a clue that's two feet long is just as valuable as one that's two millimeters long! It's the romantic notion that important clues must be tiny! As for the lead piping having no connection to the crime, you say that because Giraud told you so. No,” Poirot stopped me before I could ask. “Let's not discuss it further. Let Giraud continue his search, and me with my thoughts. The case appears simple, and yet and yet, my friend, I'm not content! And do you know why? Because of the wristwatch that's two hours ahead. And then there are several odd details that don't seem to fit. For example, if the murderers sought revenge, why didn't they simply stab Renauld while he slept and be done with it?” “They wanted the ‘secret,’” I reminded him. Poirot brushed a speck of dust off his sleeve with a dissatisfied expression. “Well, where is this ‘secret’? Presumably far away, since they wanted him to dress himself.”

At the stroke of eleven, a telegram arrived from Poirot: "Instruct Japp to detain housekeeper at once." I was shocked, but wasted no time in delivering the message to Japp. He muttered a curse, acknowledging Poirot's reputation. "If he insists, there must be a reason. I barely gave the woman a second thought. I may not arrest her, but she will be closely monitored. Let's head up there now and conduct a thorough search." Unfortunately, it was already too late. Mrs. Middleton, the unassuming middle-aged housekeeper who had seemed so ordinary, had vanished without a trace. Only her abandoned belongings remained.

After careful consideration, it was decided that I would accompany Suzanne, no matter her location, and focus solely on my own well-being. It was imperative that I refrained from seeking out thrills or trying to outsmart the elusive “Colonel.” My task was to stay by her side and await further instructions from Harry. The precious diamonds were to be securely stored in the Bank at Kimberley under the alias of Parker. "There's one aspect we must address," I pondered, "we should establish a code of sorts. We must avoid falling for deceitful messages claiming to be from one another." "That's simple. Any communication legitimately from me will have the word 'and' crossed out."

As the night drew to a close, I managed to convince her to let me walk her to the edge of town. We retraced our path, passing by the cemetery once more before veering off onto a different road. When we reached the first row of shops, she paused and extended her hand. "Thank you for coming with me," she said. "Are you sure you'll be alright now?" I inquired. "Yes, I'll be fine. I hope you won't face any repercussions for showing me around," she replied. I assured her that it was not a concern. "Well then, goodbye." "Au revoir," I interjected. "If you're sticking around, we'll cross paths once more."

I approached Pagett on the platform, eager to speak with him. He seemed startled by my presence, his usual nervous demeanor even more pronounced this time. "Miss Beddingfeld, I thought you had vanished," he exclaimed. The train had arrived just ten minutes behind schedule, with everyone hastily disembarking and pacing back and forth. The hotel porter had mentioned that the train's journey to Johannesburg was going smoothly today, despite doubts due to a recent explosion along the line. It was a surprisingly cheerful notion, considering the circumstances.

"We abandoned her at Villa Marguerite, headed straight to Villa Geneviève, and yet she beat us there!" "No, we didn't actually leave her behind. She slipped out the back of Villa Marguerite while we were conversing with her mother in the entrance. That's how she managed to outsmart Hercule Poirot!" "But the shadow on the blind? We spotted it from the street." "Well, by the time we glanced up, Madame Daubreuil had swiftly ascended the stairs and positioned herself." "Madame Daubreuil?" "Indeed. One is elderly, the other youthful, one brunette, and the other blonde, but their silhouettes on the blind are remarkably similar for this purpose."

Poirot and his companion arrived at Marsdon Leigh to investigate the death of Mr. Maltravers, who was found dead in his grounds with signs of internal hemorrhage. The doctor, Dr. Bernard, confirmed the cause of death and mentioned Mr. Maltravers' financial troubles. Mrs. Maltravers, the widow, was questioned about the events leading up to her husband's death. Poirot noticed a slight discrepancy but decided to close the case and return to London. As they were leaving, they encountered a tall young man walking towards them.

"May I inquire about the departure times of the final train from Merlinville station?" questioned Poirot. "The schedule shows eleven-fifty going one direction and 12:17 in the other, however the possibility of a waiting motor seems more feasible." Poirot, appearing slightly disappointed, nodded in agreement. "Indeed, that could be a valuable lead," remarked the magistrate optimistically. "A motor with two foreigners would surely attract attention. Well noted, M. Bex." With a brief smile, the magistrate turned serious once more, addressing Mrs. Renauld, "Now, there is another matter to discuss."

"Sir Eustace, the situation is rather suspicious in my opinion. Just consider my illness before our journey," Pagett remarked. Interrupting sharply, I stated, "Your illness was simply a bout of indigestion. You are prone to such episodes." Pagett looked uneasy. "This was different. I suspect foul play." "Please spare me the details of your ailment, Pagett. I have no interest in hearing them," I replied. "Very well, Sir Eustace. But I am convinced that I was intentionally poisoned!" "Ah," I mused. "You've been influenced by Rayburn." Pagett remained silent.

The farm was not prosperous, leading the older brother, Andrew, to move to Australia where he found success through land speculation, eventually becoming wealthy. The younger brother, Roger (my father), had no interest in farming and instead worked as a clerk after some self-education. He married up, to my mother, the daughter of a struggling artist. My father passed when I was six, and my mother followed when I was fourteen, leaving my Uncle Andrew as the only family I had left. He had just come back from Australia and purchased Crabtree Manor in our home county.

I know. But there is still much to unravel in this twisted tale of deceit and danger. The truth lies in the shadows, waiting to be brought to light. And I will not rest until justice is served and the secrets are laid bare. The game is afoot, and I am ready to play my part in this deadly dance of deception and betrayal. Let the pieces fall where they may, for the truth will always prevail in the end. And I will be there to witness it all, standing tall in the face of danger and uncertainty. This is my story, and I will see it through to the very end. Let the truth be known, no matter the cost.

I had always felt his animosity towards me. But now, the tables had turned. I was no longer the one in control, watching from the shadows. Fear began to creep in as I realized I was the target now. I had always been the obstacle in their grand plan, and I feared they would eliminate me without a second thought. Despite Harry Rayburn's past help, I knew the odds were stacked against me. Enemies lurked in every corner, closing in with each passing moment.

"I've behaved foolishly in various ways, Monsieur Poirot. I am deeply in debt but I am determined to turn things around. I care for the children and I aim to resolve my issues so we can continue living in our home. Gregory Rolf has presented me with a lucrative opportunity that could help me get back on track. I am hesitant, as I despise the idea of participating in the pretentious activities at the Chase, but I may not have a choice," He paused, meeting Poirot's sharp gaze.

"I am certain of it,” declared Poirot calmly. “May I ask a few questions, on behalf of your nephew? Who was responsible for ordering this lock from Hubbs’s?” “I took care of it myself,” Mr. Shaw responded. “I did not want to leave it in the hands of a clerk. As for the keys, Mr. Ridgeway had one, and the other two were kept by my associate and I.” “Have any clerks had the opportunity to access them?” Mr. Shaw glanced at Mr. Vavasour for confirmation. “To my knowledge, they have remained untouched in the safe since we placed them there on the 23rd,” Mr. Vavasour stated. “Unfortunately, my associate fell ill two weeks ago, on the very day that Philip departed from us."

"Magnificent, exquisite, magnificent," he exclaimed. "Tonight, you have truly outdone yourself." With a gallant gesture, he planted a kiss on each of her cheeks in a rather casual manner. Madame Nadina gracefully accepted the praise, a routine she had grown accustomed to, and made her way to the dressing room. The room was adorned with bouquets scattered haphazardly, modern garments hanging on hooks, and the air filled with a heady mix of floral scents and luxurious perfumes. Jeanne, the loyal dresser, attended to her mistress, chatting incessantly and showering her with exaggerated compliments. Suddenly, a knock at the door brought an abrupt halt to the conversation.

He reappeared in a subtly chastened mood. “Will you come this way, Miss Beddingfeld?” I followed him up the stairs. He knocked at the door of a room, a brisk “Come in” sounded from inside, and he opened the door and motioned to me to pass inside. Sir Eustace Pedler sprang up to greet me, genial and smiling. “Well, well, Miss Anne.” He shook me warmly by the hand. “I’m delighted to see you. Come and sit down. Not tired after your journey? That’s good.” He sat down facing me, still beaming. It left me rather at a loss. His manner was so completely natural. “Quite right to insist on being brought straight to me,” he went on. “Minks is a fool. A clever actor but a fool. That was Minks you saw downstairs.” “Oh, really,” I said feebly. “And now,” said Sir Eustace cheerfully, “let’s get down to facts. How long have you known that I was the ‘Colonel’?” “Ever since Mr. Pagett told me that he had seen you in Marlow when you were supposed to be in Cannes.” Sir Eustace nodded ruefully. “Yes, I told the fool he’d blinking well torn it. He didn’t understand of course. His whole mind was set on whether I’d recognized him. It never occurred to him to wonder what I was doing down there. A piece of sheer bad luck that was. I arranged it all so carefully too, sending him off to Florence, telling the hotel I was going over to Nice for one night or possibly two. Then, by the time the murder was discovered, I was back again in Cannes, with nobody dreaming that I’d ever left the Riviera.” He still spoke quite naturally and unaffectedly. I had to pinch myself to understand that this was all real that the man in front of me was really that deep-dyed criminal, the “Colonel.” I followed things out in my mind. “Then it was you who tried to throw me overboard on the Kilmorden,” I said slowly. “It was you that Pagett followed up on deck that night?” He shrugged his shoulders. “I apologize, my dear child, I really do. I always liked you but you were so confoundedly interfering. I couldn’t have all my plans brought to naught by a chit of a girl.” “I think your plan at the Falls was really the cleverest,” I said, endeavouring to look at the thing in a detached fashion. “I would have been ready to swear anywhere that you were in the hotel when I went out. Seeing is believing in future.” “Yes, Minks had one of his greatest successes as Miss Pettigrew, and he can imitate my voice quite creditably.” “There is one thing I should like to know.” “Yes?” “How did you induce Pagett to engage her?” “Oh, that was quite simple. She met Pagett in the doorway of the Trade Commissioner’s office or the Chamber of Mines, or wherever it was he went told him I had phoned down in a hurry, and that she had been selected by the Government department in question.

I trailed behind him, silently mimicking the Barotsi woman I had once observed near the Falls. Unlike her, I wasn't balancing a frying-pan on my head. His pace was so brisk, it proved challenging to keep pace. "Harry," I finally spoke up, my voice meek, "are we trekking all the way to Rhodesia?" Abruptly, he turned, bursting into laughter as he swept me off my feet. "I'm crazy, my love, I admit it. But I adore you so much." "We're both insane. And, Harry, you never asked, but I'm not sacrificing anything! I wanted this journey!" That was a couple of years back. We're still residing on the island.

“What’s this?” “The sleeve of my coat that I removed, can you brush it for me? Look, some white powder has stuck to it. Did you see me run my finger along the dressing-table drawer?” “No, I didn’t.” “You must pay attention to my movements, my friend. That’s how I ended up with the powder on my finger, and, in my excitement, I rubbed it on my sleeve in a moment of carelessness, going against all my principles.” “But what was the powder?” I inquired, showing little concern for Poirot’s principles.

Mr. Lowen expressed his apologies and bid farewell. "Everyone is aware that Mr. Davenheim never came back. The police were notified early Sunday morning, but were baffled by the situation. Mr. Davenheim appeared to have disappeared without a trace. He had not visited the post office, nor had he been spotted in the village. Authorities confirmed he had not left by train. His personal vehicle remained in the garage. If he had arranged for a car to meet him in a remote location, it is likely that the driver would have come forward by now, given the substantial reward for any information."

“If you don’t like the post, send one of your young Foreign Office fellows. He’ll enjoy the trip.” “Impossible,” said Milray, shaking his head in a dismissive manner. “There are reasons, my dear Pedler I assure you there are reasons.” “Well,” I said, standing up, “all this is very intriguing, but I must take my leave.” “One moment, my dear Pedler, one moment, I implore you. Now, tell me, in confidence, do you not plan on traveling to South Africa soon yourself? You have significant investments in Rhodesia, I understand, and the issue of Rhodesia joining the Union is one that greatly concerns you.”

Carton and She had arranged to meet at the location, pretending that their encounter was by chance. They were both there to see the same house and had taken measures to avoid being tracked. Little did Carton know, the person following him was the mysterious 'Man in the Brown Suit.' The shock of this realization caused Carton to panic and make a fatal misstep. Does this all make sense to you, Anne?" Anne remained silent. "That's the gist of it. Carton obtained a document from the deceased individual, but in his haste to escape, he accidentally dropped it. He then trailed the woman all the way to Marlow.

"She feigned great interest in our discovery, and we shared all the details with her, even revealing the diamonds. Delilah, a fitting name for her deceptive ways, played her role convincingly! The De Beers heist was uncovered, and suddenly the police swooped in. They confiscated our diamonds. Initially, we found the situation laughable. However, when the diamonds were presented in court, there was no doubt - they were the stolen De Beers gems. Anita Grünberg had vanished, successfully executing the switch. Our claim that these were not the original stones fell on deaf ears, met with ridicule."

"The revolver found at Ealing was not the murder weapon used on Mr. Pace," Poirot stated confidently. "Roger Havering, with the help of his wife, carefully orchestrated a plan to mislead the police and divert attention away from Derbyshire. Mrs. Havering shot Mr. Pace after dinner, reloaded the revolver, and cunningly placed it back in its original spot. Their plan was meticulously executed, leading to the unfortunate passing of Mr. Pace and the Havering couple in the Air Mail crash to Paris. Despite Japp's efforts, justice was not served in the end, as the murderers got away with Mr. Pace's fortune. The world of crime is full of twists and turns, my friend," Poirot mused, as we pondered the dark realities of deception and greed.

“When I woke up the next day, my nerves were shot. I knew I had to investigate. Immediately, I came face to face with you. You remember all of it… When I saw the corpse, resembling Jack so closely and draped in his elegant overcoat, I was certain! And there was that same paper-knife, the one Jack had gifted Bella! It probably bore her fingerprints. The fear I felt in that moment is indescribable. The only thing I was sure of was that I needed to obtain that dagger and make my escape before it was missed. I feigned a fainting spell, and while you were getting water, I snatched the dagger and concealed it on my person. “I had claimed to be staying at the Hôtel du Phare, but in reality, I hurried back to Calais and then to England on the first available boat. When we were in the middle of the Channel, I disposed of that malevolent little dagger in the sea. It was only then that I felt a sense of relief. “Bella was at our residence in London. She was a sight to behold. I confessed my actions to her and reassured her that she was safe for the time being. Her reaction was chilling, as she burst into laughter… laughter… laughter… a sound that sent shivers down my spine! I believed it was best to keep her occupied. She would lose her mind if she dwelled on her deeds. Fortunately, we secured employment immediately. “And then, I spotted you and your companion observing us that night… I was in a state of panic. You must have had suspicions, or else you wouldn’t have traced us. I needed to know the worst, so I followed you. I was desperate. It soon dawned on me that you were pointing fingers at me, not Bella! Or perhaps, you mistook me for Bella since I had taken the dagger. “If only you could have seen what was going through my mind in that moment… maybe you would have forgiven me… I was terrified, confused, and desperate… All I could grasp was that you would attempt to protect me. I wasn’t sure if you’d be willing to do the same for her… I doubted it! It wasn’t the same! And I couldn’t take that risk! Bella is my twin sister, I had to do what was best for her. So, I continued to lie… I felt guilty, and I still do… That’s probably more than enough for you to handle, I assume. I should have put my faith in you… If only I had. “Once the newspapers reported Jack Renauld’s arrest, it was all over. Bella didn’t even wait to see how things played out… “I’m exhausted… I can’t continue writing…” She had started signing as Cinderella, but then crossed it out and wrote “Dulcie Duveen” instead. It was a poorly written, smudged letter, but I have kept it all these years. Poirot was by my side as I read it. The papers slipped from my hands, and I glanced at him. “Did you know all along that it was the other one?” “Yes, my friend.” “Why didn’t you inform me?” “Initially, I couldn’t believe that you could make such an error. You had seen the photograph. The sisters are very similar, but not impossible to tell apart.” “But the blonde hair?” “A wig, worn for dramatic effect on the stage. Is it conceivable for twins to have such contrasting hair colors?” “Why didn’t you tell me that evening at the hotel in Coventry?” “You were a bit too forceful in your methods, mon ami,” Poirot remarked dryly. “You didn’t give me a chance.” “And later?” “Ah, later! At first, I was hurt by your lack of trust in me. And then, I wanted to see if your feelings would endure. To see if it was love or just a passing infatuation. I wouldn’t have let you remain in error for too long.” I nodded. His tone was too affectionate for me to hold a grudge. I gazed down at the letter. Suddenly, I picked it up from the ground, and slid it over to him. “Read this,” I urged. “I want you to.” He read it silently, then looked up at me. “What’s troubling you, Hastings?” This was a new side of Poirot. His usual mocking demeanor seemed to have vanished. I was able to express my concerns without much difficulty. “She doesn’t explicitly say, well, not whether she has feelings for me or not!” Poirot flipped through the pages. “I believe you are mistaken, Hastings.” “Where?” I exclaimed, leaning in eagerly. Poirot smiled. “She conveys it in every line of the letter, mon ami.” “But how do I find her? There’s no address on the letter. Only a French stamp.” “Don’t fret! Leave it to Papa Poirot. I can locate her for you in a matter of minutes!” “Congratulations, Mr. Jack,” said Poirot, shaking the young man’s hand warmly. Young Renauld had rushed to us the moment he was released, before heading back to Merlinville to reunite with Marthe and his mother. Stonor accompanied him. Jack’s enthusiasm was a stark contrast to the boy’s weary appearance. It was evident that he was on the brink of a breakdown. Despite being saved from the immediate danger that loomed over him, the circumstances of his freedom were too distressing for him to feel complete relief. He gave Poirot a sad smile and said quietly: “I went through all this to protect her, and now it’s all in vain!” “You couldn’t expect the girl to accept the price of your life,” Stonor remarked dryly. “She was bound to come forward when she saw you heading towards the gallows.” “Well, and you were heading there too!” added Poirot, with a hint of amusement. “You would have been responsible for Maître Grosíer’s death by sheer frustration had you proceeded.” “He meant well, I suppose,” said Jack. “But he drove me crazy. You see, I couldn’t really confide in him. But, damn it all! What’s going to happen to Bella?” “If I were you,” Poirot said frankly, “I wouldn’t worry excessively. The French legal system is lenient towards youth, beauty, and crimes of passion. A skilled lawyer can argue a strong case for extenuating circumstances. It won’t be pleasant for you.” “I’m not bothered about that. You see, Mr. Poirot, in a way I feel responsible for my father’s murder. If it weren’t for me and my involvement with this girl, he would still be alive and well today. And then my careless mistake in taking the wrong coat. I can’t shake off the feeling of guilt for his death.”

I was enjoying an evening with my friend, Gerald Parker. The conversation turned to house-hunting in London, a topic Parker was passionate about. He had moved from one flat to another, always finding new places. Mrs. Robinson shared that she and her husband had finally found a flat in Montagu Mansions for a surprisingly low price. Parker was astonished by the good deal, suspecting there must be a catch. Mrs. Robinson seemed uneasy, mentioning some strange things about the place that made her wonder if it was haunted. Parker dismissed the idea, but Mrs. Robinson was not convinced.

"As the Prime Minister and his secretary, Captain Daniels, traveled back to town after an Audience in Windsor, the car deviated from the main road and was ambushed by masked men. Shots were fired, narrowly missing the Prime Minister, who downplayed the incident as a scratch. The car was later found abandoned outside a suspicious restaurant in Soho, with the chauffeur, O'Murphy, missing. Poirot, asked to investigate, is granted carte blanche to do so with the assistance of a Military officer and a C.I.D. man. The urgency of the situation is evident as uncertainties arise about the loyalty of those involved."

Silently, the Kilmorden approached closer and closer, like a dream to Anne Beddingfeld. As she marveled at the world around her, she noticed a figure by her side. It was Rayburn, the man she had encountered the night before. His warning about the dangerous business she was involved in sent shivers down her spine. He advised her to be cautious and not to meddle in affairs that could put her in harm's way. Despite her confusion, Rayburn's words struck a chord with her. She couldn't help but wonder why he was going out of his way to protect her.

Poirot, Bex, and Giraud were gathered in the room, discussing the disappearance of a dagger from the glass jar. Hastings then admitted his grave fault of showing a young lady the body, leaving the door unlocked for twenty minutes. The commissary found it deplorable, but Giraud surprisingly called it admirable, suggesting that the assassin or an accomplice had been near the Villa recently. Poirot noted that the assassin wore gloves, ensuring no fingerprints were left on the dagger. The magistrate's clerk began gathering the papers as M. Hautet announced the end of their work in the room.

Nadina, the Russian dancer, took her final bow on stage, accepting praise from the Manager. After the performance, she received a visit from Count Sergius Paulovitch, who congratulated her on her success. As they conversed in English, Nadina revealed a secret to the Count - she possessed diamonds that could be used to blackmail their chief, the 'Colonel.' The Count warned her of the dangers of blackmailing such a man, but Nadina remained confident in her plan. She disclosed that her husband, who was arriving from Africa, was also involved in their scheme to confront the 'Colonel.' Despite the Count's doubts, Nadina was resolute in her decision to take on their powerful adversary.

“I’m instructing you on how to face reality head-on. I’m teaching you to embrace toughness and ruthlessness, qualities that have led to my own success.” “I’d rather be dead than lose my compassion,” I declared fervently. We climbed into the car and set off. I took a moment to compose myself. Then, unexpectedly, he reached for my hand. “Anne,” he murmured softly, “I need you. Will you marry me?” I was caught off guard. “Oh, no,” I faltered. “I can’t.” “Why not?” “I don’t have romantic feelings for you. I’ve never seen you in that light.” “I understand. Is that the only reason?” I knew I had to be truthful. I owed him that much. “No,” I confessed, “it is not.”

"But what was the true intent? What was the real purpose scheduled for one o’clock in Cabin 17? It couldn't have been the secretary's stabbing. Scheduling it for a specific hour on a specific day in a specific location would serve no purpose. No, it must have been some sort of meeting and he was en route to attend it when he was attacked. But who was the meeting with? Definitely not with you. It could have been with Chichester. Or perhaps with Pagett.” “That doesn't seem likely,” I interjected, “they could meet at any time.” We both fell silent for a couple of minutes, then Suzanne veered off in a different direction.

A second diamond, identical in shape and size, served as the right eye. Legend had it that this gem too would eventually be taken. 'One eye will head West, the other East, until they reunite. Then, they will come back to the deity in glory.' It's interesting to note that there exists currently a gem closely resembling this one, referred to as 'the Star of the West' or 'the Western Star.' This precious stone belongs to the renowned movie star, Mary Marvell. A side-by-side analysis of these two jewels would be fascinating." She fell silent.

I wonder what secrets Pagett is hiding. He always seems to know more than he lets on. But tonight, it's all about the Fancy Dress dance. Mrs. Blair and Race are both on the guest list. The Beddingfeld girl, with those perfect legs, will be joining us as well. Pagett, however, seems to have other plans. Instead, a man named Reeves will be accompanying us. He’s like all the rest of these people, they make inflammatory speeches of enormous length, solely for political purposes, and then wish they hadn’t. He’s busy now going about and saying he didn’t really do it. When I met him, he was just off to Cape Town, where he meditates making a three days’ speech in Dutch, vindicating himself, and pointing out that the things he said really meant something entirely different. I am thankful that I do not have to sit in the Legislative Assembly of South Africa. The House of Commons is bad enough, but at least we have only one language, and some slight restriction as to length of speeches. When I went to the Assembly before leaving Cape Town, I listened to a gray-haired gentleman with a drooping moustache who looked exactly like the Mock Turtle in Alice in Wonderland. He dropped out his words one by one in a particularly melancholy fashion. Every now and then he galvanized himself to further efforts by ejaculating something that sounded like “Platt Skeet,” uttered fortissimo and in marked contrast to the rest of his delivery. When he did this, half his audience yelled “Whoof, whoof!” which is possibly Dutch for “Hear, hear,” and the other half woke up with a start from the pleasant nap they had been having. I was given to understand that the gentleman had been speaking for at least three days. They must have a lot of patience in South Africa. I have invented endless jobs to keep Pagett in Cape Town, but at last the fertility of my imagination has given out, and he joins me to-morrow in the spirit of the faithful dog who comes to die by his master’s side. And I was getting on so well with my Reminiscences too! I had invented some extraordinarily witty things that the strike leaders said to me and I said to the strike leaders. This morning I was interviewed by a Government official. He was urbane, persuasive and mysterious in turn. To begin with, he alluded to my exalted position and importance and suggested that I should remove myself, or be removed by him, to Pretoria. “You expect trouble, then?” I asked. His reply was so worded as to have no meaning whatsoever, so I gathered that they were expecting serious trouble. I suggested to him that his Government were letting things go rather far. “There is such a thing as giving a man enough rope, and letting him hang himself, Sir Eustace.” “Oh, quite so, quite so.” “It is not the strikers themselves who are causing the trouble. There is some organization at work behind them. Arms and explosives have been pouring in, and we have made a haul of certain documents which throw a good deal of light on the methods adopted to import them. There is a regular code. Potatoes mean ‘detonators,’ cauliflower, ‘rifles,’ other vegetables stand for various explosives.” “That’s very interesting,” I commended. “More than that, Sir Eustace, we have every reason to believe that the man who runs the whole show, the directing genius of the affair, is at this minute in Johannesburg.” He stared at me so hard that I began to fear that he suspected me of being the man. I broke out into a cold perspiration at the thought, and began to regret that I had ever conceived the idea of inspecting a miniature revolution at first hand. “No trains are running from Jo’burg to Pretoria,” he continued. “But I can arrange to send you over by private car. In case you should be stopped on the way I can provide you with two separate passes, one issued by the Union Government, and the other stating that you are an English visitor who has nothing whatsoever to do with the Union.” “One for your people, and one for the strikers, eh?” “Exactly.” The project did not appeal to me I know what happens in a case of that kind. You get flustered and mix the things up. I should hand the wrong pass to the wrong person, and it would end in my being summarily shot by a bloodthirsty rebel, or one of the supporters of law and order whom I notice guarding the streets wearing bowler hats and smoking pipes, with rifles tucked carelessly under their arms. Besides, what should I do with myself in Pretoria? Admire the architecture of the Union buildings and listen to the echoes of the shooting round Johannesburg? I should be penned up there God knows how long. They’ve blown up the railway line already, I hear. It isn’t even as if one could get a drink there. They put the place under martial law two days ago. “My dear fellow,” I said, “you don’t seem to realize that I’m studying conditions on the Rand. How the devil am I going to study them from Pretoria? I appreciate your care for my safety, but don’t you worry about me. I shall be all right.” “I warn you, Sir Eustace, that the food question is already serious.” “A little fasting will improve my figure,” I said, with a sigh. We were interrupted by a telegram being handed to me. I read it with amazement: “Anne is safe. Here with me at Kimberley. Suzanne Blair.” I don’t think I ever really believed in the annihilation of Anne. There is something peculiarly indestructible about that young woman she is like the patent balls that one gives to terriers. She has an extraordinary knack of turning up smiling. I still don’t see why it was necessary for her to walk out of the hotel in the middle of the night in order to get to Kimberley. There was no train, anyway. She must have put on a pair of angel’s wings and flown there. And I don’t suppose she will ever explain. Nobody does to me. I always have to guess. It becomes monotonous after a while. The exigencies of journalism are at the bottom of it, I suppose. “How I shot the rapids,” by our Special Correspondent. I refolded the telegram and got rid of my Governmental friend.

And this ridiculous routine of waking up at 5 a.m. upon arriving at the port to see a doctor and raise your hands in the air simply exhausts me. Later on. A very serious development has taken place. I went to my meeting with the Prime Minister, carrying Milray's sealed letter. It didn't appear tampered with, but inside was just a blank sheet of paper! Now, I assume, I am in quite a mess. Why I allowed that foolish Milray to entangle me in this affair is beyond me. Pagett is reveling in my discomfort. He seems to take pleasure in my misery. Additionally, he has taken advantage of my distress to burden me with the stationery trunk. If he's not careful, the next funeral he attends will be his own. However, in the end, I had to listen to him. "Imagine, Sir Eustace, if Rayburn had overheard a snippet of your conversation with Mr. Milray on the street? Remember, you had no written authorization from Mr. Milray. You trusted Rayburn based on his own word." "So you believe Rayburn is a criminal, then?" I inquired slowly. Pagett did indeed. How much his opinion was influenced by his black eye, I cannot say. He presented a fairly convincing case against Rayburn. And Rayburn's appearance didn't help his case. My plan was to do nothing about it. A man who has allowed himself to be made a fool of is not eager to publicize the fact. But Pagett, undeterred by his recent misfortunes, was all for taking decisive action. He rushed off to the police station, sent numerous cables, and brought a slew of English and Dutch officials to enjoy whiskies and sodas at my expense. We received Milray's response that evening. He had no knowledge of my former secretary! There was only one silver lining to this whole situation. "At least," I remarked to Pagett, "you were not poisoned. You simply had one of your usual stomach problems." I saw him flinch. It was my lone triumph. Later on. Pagett is in his element. His mind is brimming with bright ideas. He is now convinced that Rayburn is none other than the infamous "Man in the Brown Suit." He may very well be correct. But this is all becoming quite unpleasant. The sooner I depart for Rhodesia, the better. I have explained to Pagett that he is not to accompany me. "You understand, my dear fellow," I stated, "you must stay here. You may need to identify Rayburn at any moment. And, besides, I must consider my dignity as a British Member of Parliament. "But what will you do about your correspondence and speech notes, Sir Eustace?" "I'll manage," I replied nonchalantly. Alone in my room, I retrieved my precious note and examined it closely. This held the key to the enigma. Firstly, what did the numbers signify? There were five of them, with a period after the first two. "Seventeen one hundred and twenty-two," I whispered. It didn't seem to lead anywhere. Next, I added them together. This was a common tactic in fiction, leading to unexpected conclusions. "One and seven make eight, one is nine, two are eleven, two are thirteen." Thirteen! An ominous number! Was this a warning for me to steer clear of the entire affair? Possibly. Nonetheless, apart from a warning, it appeared to be rather useless. I refused to believe that any schemer would use this method of writing thirteen in reality. If they meant thirteen, they would write it as "13" straightforwardly. There was a gap between the one and the two. Hence, I subtracted twenty-two from a hundred and seventy-one. The answer was a hundred and fifty-nine. I repeated the process and arrived at a hundred and forty-nine. These mathematical exercises were likely beneficial as practice, but in terms of solving the puzzle, they seemed entirely fruitless. I abandoned arithmetic, refraining from fanciful divisions or multiplications, and shifted my focus to the words. Kilmorden Castle. That was a concrete lead."

He observed me intently for a few moments. “Yes, I understand perfectly. And you are wise. Stick to your story.” “That seems to always be your advice,” I stated, slightly offended. “Ah, my friend, trust in Papa Poirot. One day, with your permission, I will arrange a marriage for you with great suitability.” “Thank you,” I chuckled, “but the idea doesn’t excite me.” Poirot sighed and shook his head. “The English!” he muttered. “No method at all. They leave everything to chance!” He scowled, adjusting the position of the salt cellar. “You mentioned that Miss Cinderella is staying at the Hôtel d’Angleterre, correct?” “No. Hôtel du Phare.” “Right, I forgot.” A brief moment of doubt crossed my mind. Had I ever told Poirot which hotel the girl was staying at? I glanced at him and felt reassured. He was meticulously cutting his bread into small squares, completely focused on the task. He must have assumed I had informed him of her whereabouts. We enjoyed coffee outside by the sea. Poirot smoked one of his miniature cigarettes before checking his watch. “The train to Paris departs at 2:25,” he noted. “I should get going.” “Paris?” I exclaimed. “Indeed, that’s what I said, my friend.” “You’re heading to Paris? But why?” He responded gravely. “To find the murderer of Mr. Renauld.” “You believe he’s in Paris?” “I am certain he is not. Nonetheless, that is where I must search for him. You don’t comprehend, but I will explain everything in due time. Trust me, this journey to Paris is imperative. I won’t be gone long. Most likely, I’ll return tomorrow. I don’t suggest you accompany me. Stay here and keep an eye on Giraud. Also, get to know Mr. Renauld’s son. And if you wish, try to win over Mademoiselle Marthe. Though, I doubt you’ll have much luck.” I wasn’t pleased with his last comment. “By the way,” I began, “I meant to ask how you knew about those two?” “My friend, I understand human nature. Put a boy like young Renauld together with a lovely girl like Mademoiselle Marthe, and the outcome is nearly inevitable. Then, the argument! It was either money or a woman, and recalling Léonie’s description of the lad’s anger, I went with the latter. So I made a guess, and I was correct.” “So that’s why you cautioned me against getting attached to the lady? You already suspected that she cared for young Renauld?” Poirot grinned. “At the very least, I noticed she had worried eyes. That’s how I always think of Mademoiselle Daubreuil - the girl with the anxious eyes…” His tone was so serious that it made me uneasy. “What do you mean by that, Poirot?” “I believe, my friend, that we will soon find out. But I must leave.” “You have plenty of time.” “Maybe maybe. But I prefer to have ample time at the station. I don’t want to rush, to hurry, to agitate myself.” “In any case,” I said, getting up, “I’ll come and see you off.” “You will do no such thing. I forbid it.” He was so authoritative that I stared at him in astonishment. He nodded firmly. “I mean it, my friend. Goodbye! May I embrace you? Oh, no, I forgot it’s not the English custom. A handshake, then.” After Poirot departed, I felt somewhat lost. I wandered down the beach, observing the swimmers, but lacking the energy to join in. I half expected Cinderella to be among them in some extravagant outfit, but she was nowhere to be seen. I aimlessly walked along the shore towards the other end of town. It occurred to me that, at the very least, it would be polite to inquire about the girl. And it would save me trouble in the long run. The issue would then be resolved. I wouldn’t have to worry about her anymore. But if I didn’t go at all, she might come looking for me at the Villa. And that would be inconvenient in every way. Without a doubt, it was better to pay a brief visit, during which I could make it clear that I could no longer assist her as a guide. So, I left the beach and headed inland. I soon located the Hôtel du Phare, a modest structure. It was incredibly frustrating not to know the lady’s name, and to save face, I decided to casually enter and look around. Most likely, I would find her in the lounge. Merlinville was a small town - you left your hotel to go to the beach, and you left the beach to return to the hotel. There were no other attractions. A Casino was under construction, but it was not yet finished. Since I had traversed the entire beach without spotting her, she must be in the hotel. I entered. Several individuals were seated in the cramped lounge, but she was not among them. I peeked into other rooms, but there was no sign of her. I waited for a while, until impatience got the best of me. I discreetly approached the concierge, slipping him five francs. “I need to see a lady staying here. A young English lady, petite and dark-haired. I’m not certain of her name.” The man shook his head, barely concealing a smile. “There is no lady matching that description staying here.” “Perhaps she’s American,” I suggested. These people are so dim. But the man continued to shake his head. “No, sir. There are only six or seven English and American ladies here, and they are all older than the lady you’re looking for. You won’t find her here, sir.” His certainty made me doubt myself. “But the lady informed me she was staying here.” “You or the lady must have been mistaken, since another gentleman was here asking for her.” “What do you mean?” I asked, surprised. “Yes, sir. A gentleman described her just as you did.” “What was he like?” “He was a small, well-dressed man, very tidy, with a stiff mustache, a peculiarly shaped head, and green eyes.” Poirot! So that’s why he didn’t want me to go to the station with him.

He returned grinning. “That’s all right, miss. We can go along.” He led the way to 17. It was not quite as large as No. 13, but I found it eminently satisfactory. “I’ll fetch your things right away, miss,” said the steward. But at that moment, the man with the sinister face (as I had nicknamed him) appeared in the doorway. “Excuse me,” he said, “but this cabin is reserved for the use of Sir Eustace Pedler.” “That’s all right, sir,” explained the steward. “We’re fitting up No. 13 instead.” “No, it was No. 17 I was to have.” “No. 13 is a better cabin, sir larger.” “I specially selected No. 17, and the purser said I could have it.” “I’m sorry,” I said coldly. “But No. 17 has been allotted to me.” “I can’t agree to that.” The steward put in his oar. “The other cabin’s just the same, only better.” “I want No. 17.” “What’s all this?” demanded a new voice. “Steward, put my things in here. This is my cabin.” It was my neighbor at lunch, the Rev. Edward Chichester. “I beg your pardon,” I said. “It’s my cabin.” “It is allotted to Sir Eustace Pedler,” said Mr. Pagett. We were all getting rather heated. “I’m sorry to have to dispute the matter,” said Chichester with a meek smile which failed to mask his determination to get his own way. Meek men are always obstinate, I have noticed. He edged himself sideways into the doorway. “You’re to have No. 28 on the port side,” said the steward. “A very good cabin, sir.” “I am afraid that I must insist. No. 17 was the cabin promised to me.” We had come to an impasse. Each one of us was determined not to give way. Strictly speaking, I, at any rate, might have retired from the contest and eased matters by offering to accept Cabin 28. So long as I did not have 13 it was immaterial to me what other cabin I had. But my blood was up. I had not the least intention of being the first to give way. And I disliked Chichester. He had false teeth which clicked when he ate. Many men have been hated for less. We all said the same things over again. The steward assured us, even more strongly, that both the other cabins were better cabins. None of us paid any attention to him. Pagett began to lose his temper. Chichester kept his serenely. With an effort I also kept mine. And still none of us would give way an inch. A wink and a whispered word from the steward gave me my cue. I faded unobtrusively from the scene. I was lucky enough to encounter the purser almost immediately. “Oh, please,” I said, “you did say I could have Cabin 17? And the others won’t go away. Mr. Chichester and Mr. Pagett. You will let me have it, won’t you?” I always say that there are no people like sailors for being nice to women. My little purser came to the scratch splendidly. He strode to the scene, informed the disputants that No. 17 was my cabin, they could have Nos. 13 and 28 respectively or stay where they were whichever they chose. I permitted my eyes to tell him what a hero he was and then installed myself in my new domain. The encounter had done me worlds of good. The sea was smooth, the weather growing daily warmer. Sea-sickness was a thing of the past! I went up on deck and was initiated into the mysteries of deck-quoits. I entered my name for various sports. Tea was served on deck, and I ate heartily. After tea, I played shovel-board with some pleasant young men. They were extraordinarily nice to me. I felt that life was satisfactory and delightful. The dressing bugle came as a surprise and I hurried to my new cabin. The stewardess was awaiting me with a troubled face. “There’s a terrible smell in your cabin, miss. What it is, I’m sure I can’t think, but I doubt if you’ll be able to sleep here. There’s a deck cabin up on C deck, I believe. You might move into that just for the night, anyway.” The smell really was pretty bad quite nauseating. I told the stewardess I would think over the question of moving whilst I dressed. I hurried over my toilet, sniffing distastefully as I did so. What was the smell? Dead rat? No, worse than that and quite different. Yet I knew it! It was something I had smelt before. Something Ah! I had got it. Asafœtida! I had worked in a Hospital dispensary during the war for a short time and had become acquainted with various nauseous drugs. Asafœtida, that was it. But how I sank down on the sofa, suddenly realizing the thing. Somebody had put a pinch of asafœtida in my cabin. Why? So that I should vacate it? Why were they so anxious to get me out? I thought of the scene this afternoon from a rather different point of view. What was there about Cabin 17 that made so many people anxious to get hold of it? The other two cabins were better cabins, why had both men insisted on sticking to 17? 17.

"What do you mean by ‘vanish’? To which category of vanishing are you alluding?” “Are vanishings organized and categorized, then?” I chuckled. Japp grinned as well. Poirot scowled at us both. “But of course they are! They are divided into three groups: First, and most frequent, the deliberate vanishing act. Second, the often falsified ‘amnesia’ scenario, uncommon, but occasionally legitimate. Third, homicide, and the more or less effective disposal of the corpse. Do you consider all three as unattainable?” “Almost certainly, I would say. You may lose your own memory, but someone would surely identify you particularly in the instance of a prominent figure like Davenheim.”

The Villa was shrouded in darkness, with everyone fast asleep. As we stood beneath Mrs. Renauld's open window, a cry for help shattered the stillness. A light flickered in a nearby room as a struggle ensued. Poirot sprang into action, scaling a tree with feline agility. I followed, watching as Cinderella, the acrobat, swung effortlessly towards the danger. In a daring rescue, she averted a tragedy just in time. The scene unfolded, revealing the sinister truth behind the murder of M. Renauld and the attempted murder of his wife. The pieces fell into place, leading us to the unexpected culprit, Marthe Daubreuil. Through a series of clever deductions, the mystery was unraveled, exposing the cold-blooded motives of a calculating killer.

I presented myself as a potential renter. My target was the local real estate agents, who had a limited number of properties available. However, I underestimated my opponent. A friendly clerk provided details on several attractive properties. I had to use all my cunning to come up with flaws for each one. In the end, I was afraid I had hit a dead end. "Do you have anything else?" I inquired, feigning desperation. "Perhaps something by the river, with a sizable garden and a small lodge," I mentioned, summarizing the key features of the Mill House, based on my research.

“Poirot, we need your help urgently,” Lord Estair said, his face grave. “The Prime Minister has disappeared, kidnapped on his way to France for an important conference. We must act quickly.” Poirot's brow furrowed as he listened to the details of the case. The Prime Minister's car had been ambushed, shots fired, and the driver, O’Murphy, had taken a detour off the main road, only to disappear later. The Secretary, Daniels, was found bound and gagged, but alive. There were too many unanswered questions, too many variables to consider. Poirot pondered over the situation, weighing the facts carefully. “This is a dark and complex case,” he muttered to himself. “We must proceed with caution and method.”

“As I mentioned before,” I began, “the second dagger discovered in the tramp belonged to Mrs. Renauld. This means there were two identical daggers in total.” Poirot nodded in agreement. “Indeed, and given that they were duplicates, it is logical to assume that Jack Renauld was the owner. However, what truly concerns me is the issue of psychological heredity, mon ami, heredity! Like father, like son Jack Renauld, ultimately, is the offspring of Georges Conneau.” His tone was serious and sincere, leaving me somewhat impressed. “What was that idea you mentioned earlier?” I inquired. Poirot checked his watch, then asked, “What time does the afternoon boat from Calais depart?” “Around five, I believe.” “That should work perfectly. We will have just enough time.” “Are you heading to England?” “Yes, my friend.” “For what reason?” “To track down a potential witness.” “Who?” Poirot responded with a slightly enigmatic smile, “Miss Bella Duveen.” “But how do you plan to locate her? What do you know about her?” “I may not have much information about her, but I can make some educated guesses. It is likely that her name is Bella Duveen, and considering that M. Stonor found it vaguely familiar, though not in connection to the Renauld family, it is probable that she is involved in the theater. Jack Renauld, a young man of considerable wealth, and twenty years old. The theater would have been his first love. It also aligns with M. Renauld’s attempt to appease her with a check. I am confident I will find her, especially with this.” Poirot revealed the photograph he had taken from Jack Renauld’s drawer. “With love from Bella,” was scribbled in one corner, but what captured my attention was not the message. The image, although not of the highest quality, was unmistakable to me. A sense of dread washed over me, as if some unimaginable disaster had occurred. It was Cinderella's face. I sat frozen for a moment, the photograph still in my grasp. Eventually, I composed myself and handed it back, stealing a quick glance at Poirot. Had he noticed anything? Thankfully, he seemed oblivious to any unusual behavior. Anything out of the ordinary in my demeanor had evidently gone unnoticed by him. He promptly got up. “We must depart quickly. We have no time to waste. The sea will be calm!” Amidst the commotion of our departure, I had no opportunity for reflection, but once aboard the ship, shielded from Poirot’s scrutiny (as he was, as usual, "practising the method most excellent of Laverguier"), I gathered my thoughts and analyzed the situation objectively. How much did Poirot truly know? Was he aware that my fellow traveler and Bella Duveen were one and the same? Why had he visited the Hôtel du Phare? Was it for my benefit as I had assumed? Or had I foolishly believed so, and was this visit for a deeper, more sinister purpose? But regardless, why was he so determined to find this young lady? Did he suspect her of witnessing Jack Renauld commit the crime? But that was inconceivable! The girl had no reason to harm the elder Renauld, no motive to desire his death. What had led her back to the scene of the murder? I meticulously reviewed the facts. She likely disembarked the train at Calais, where we parted ways that day. It made sense that I couldn't locate her on the boat. If she had dined in Calais and then taken a train to Merlinville, she would have arrived at the Villa Geneviève around the time Françoise mentioned. What transpired when she left the residence shortly after ten? Presumably, she either checked into a hotel or returned to Calais. And then? The crime occurred on Tuesday night. By Thursday morning, she was back in Merlinville. Did she ever leave France at all? I highly doubted it. What was keeping her there, the hope of reuniting with Jack Renauld? I had informed her (believing it at the time) that he was en route to Buenos Ayres on the high seas. Perhaps she knew the Anzora had not set sail. But to be aware of that, she must have seen Jack. Was that Poirot's objective? Had Jack Renauld, returning to meet Marthe Daubreuil, unexpectedly encountered Bella Duveen, the girl he had callously rejected? Things were beginning to make sense. If that was indeed the case, it could provide Jack with the alibi he required. Yet, under those circumstances, his silence was perplexing. Why didn't he speak up boldly? Was he afraid that this former relationship of his would come to light to Marthe Daubreuil? I shook my head, dissatisfied. It had been a harmless, foolish romance between two young individuals, and I cynically considered that the son of a millionaire was unlikely to be abandoned by an impoverished French girl who loved him deeply, without a significant reason. Overall, I found the situation perplexing and unsatisfactory. I strongly disliked being involved with Poirot in the pursuit of this girl, but I couldn't see a way out of it without divulging everything to him, something I was reluctant to do for some unknown reason. Poirot reappeared lively and cheerful upon our arrival in Dover, and our trip to London was uneventful. It was well past nine o’clock when we reached our destination, and I assumed we would head straight to our accommodations and wait until morning. However, Poirot had different plans. “We must act swiftly, mon ami. While the news of the arrest won't be in the English papers until the day after tomorrow, we mustn't delay.” I didn't quite grasp his reasoning, but I simply inquired about his strategy to locate the girl.

"I was completely shaken the next morning, feeling the urgency to investigate. I came face to face with the dead man, a striking resemblance to Jack, donning his distinctive overcoat. The unmistakable paper knife, a gift from Jack to Bella, was there too. My only thought was to possess that dagger and escape undetected. Feigning a fainting spell, I seized the weapon and concealed it on my person. I claimed to be staying at Hôtel du Phare, but in reality, I swiftly returned to Calais and then sailed to England. As the boat crossed the Channel, I disposed of the dagger, feeling a sense of relief. "Back in London, Bella's appearance was distressing. I confessed my actions to her, providing some temporary security. Her unsettling laughter echoed in the room, propelling me to keep her occupied. A chance performance provided us with an opportunity to distract ourselves. "Upon spotting you and your companion observing us that night, panic set in. Your pursuit indicated suspicion, leading me to tail you. My anxiety peaked as I realized that you mistook me for Bella, assuming I had taken the dagger. "Reflecting on that moment, my fear and desperation clouded my judgment. I harbored doubts about your intentions, torn between saving me or her. Believing it was best to prioritize Bella, my deception continued. Regrets linger, questioning if trust in you would have altered the outcome. "The news of Jack Renauld's arrest sealed Bella's fate. Exhausted, I couldn't continue writing. Signed as Cinderella but changed to Dulcie Duveen, the letter remains a poignant reminder of past events. Poirot, present during my reading, unveiled the truth. The sisters' resemblance, highlighted by Bella's wig, had misled us all along. "Poirot's explanation shed light on his silence, testing my feelings and commitment. Handing him the letter, I sought answers. Concerned by Dulcie's ambiguous sentiments, Poirot reassured me of her love. With a French stamp as the only clue, I entrusted Poirot to locate her. "In a heartfelt reunion, Poirot congratulated Jack on his release, accompanied by a grateful handshake. Despite his freedom, Jack's distress was evident, weighed down by guilt and uncertainty. As he prepared to reunite with Marthe and his mother, the shadow of Bella's future loomed large. Poirot's advice offered a glimmer of hope amidst the turmoil, emphasizing the leniency of French courts and the potential for extenuating circumstances. Jack's remorse and self-blame for his father's death lingered, overshadowing his relief from escaping the guillotine."

In the corner by the fire-place stood a large writing-table. A man, or what once was a man, sat at the table. His right hand clutched the telephone base, but he lay forward, felled by a brutal blow to the head from behind. The murder weapon was easily found - a marble statuette with a bloodstained base. The doctor’s swift examination confirmed the worst. "Stone dead. Death was quick. Surprising he even had time to make a call. Best not to disturb the body until the police come." Following the manager's advice, we combed through the apartment, but the outcome was inevitable.

"But what about the crime passionnel? Can you rule that out? If Madame Daubreuil was Renauld’s mistress, if she found that his affection was cooling, or if her jealousy was aroused in any way, might she not have struck him down in a moment of anger?” Poirot shook his head. “If I say if, you note Madame Daubreuil was Renauld’s mistress, he had not had time to tire of her. And in any case you mistake her character. She is a woman who can simulate great emotional stress. She is a magnificent actress. But, looked at dispassionately, her life disproves her appearance. Throughout, if we examine it, she had been cold-blooded and calculating in her motives and actions. It was not to link her life with that of her young lover that she connived at her husband’s murder. The rich American, for whom she probably did not care a button, was her objective. If she committed a crime, she would always do so for gain. Here there was no gain. Besides, how do you account for the digging of the grave? That was a man’s work.” “She might have had an accomplice,” I suggested, unwilling to relinquish my belief. “I pass to another objection. You have spoken of the similarity between the two crimes. Wherein does that lie, my friend?” I stared at him in astonishment. “Why, Poirot, it was you who remarked on that! The story of the masked men, the ‘secret,’ the papers!” Poirot smiled a little. “Do not be so indignant, I beg of you. I repudiate nothing. The similarity of the two stories links the two cases together inevitably. But reflect now on something very curious. It is not Madame Daubreuil who tells us this tale if it were all would indeed be plain sailing it is Madame Renauld. Is she then in league with the other?” “I can’t believe that,” I said slowly. “If it is so, she must be the most consummate actress the world has ever known.” “Ta-ta-ta,” said Poirot impatiently. “Again you have the sentiment, and not the logic! If it is necessary for a criminal to be a consummate actress, then by all means assume her to be one. But is it necessary? I do not believe Madame Renauld to be in league with Madame Daubreuil for several reasons, some of which I have already enumerated to you. The others are self-evident. Therefore, that possibility eliminated, we draw very near to the truth which is, as always, very curious and interesting.” “Poirot,” I cried, “what more do you know?” “Mon ami, you must make your own deductions. You have ‘access to the facts!’ Concentrate your grey cells. Reason not like Giraud but like Hercule Poirot.” “But are you sure?” “My friend, in many ways I have been an imbecile. But at last I see clearly.” “You know everything?” “I have discovered what M. Renauld sent for me to discover.” “And you know the murderer?” “I know one murderer.” “What do you mean?” “We talk a little at cross-purposes. There are here not one crime, but two. The first I have solved, the second eh bien, I will confess, I am not sure!” “But, Poirot, I thought you said the man in the shed had died a natural death?” “Ta-ta-ta.” Poirot made his favourite ejaculation of impatience. “Still you do not understand. One may have a crime without a murderer, but for two crimes it is essential to have two bodies.” His remark struck me as so peculiarly lacking in lucidity that I looked at him in some anxiety. But he appeared perfectly normal. Suddenly he rose and strolled to the window. “Here he is,” he observed. “Who?” “M. Jack Renauld. I sent a note up to the Villa to ask him to come here.” That changed the course of my ideas, and I asked Poirot if he knew that Jack Renauld had been in Merlinville on the night of the crime. I had hoped to catch my astute little friend napping, but as usual, he was omniscient. He, too, had inquired at the station. “And without doubt we are not original in the idea, Hastings. The excellent Giraud, he also has probably made his inquiries.” “You don’t think ” I said, and then stopped. “Ah, no, it would be too horrible!” Poirot looked inquiringly at me, but I said no more. It had just occurred to me that though there were seven women directly or indirectly connected with the case Mrs. Renauld, Madame Daubreuil and her daughter, the mysterious visitor, and the three servants there was, with the exception of old Auguste who could hardly count, only one man Jack Renauld. And a man must have dug a grave.… I had no time to develop further the appalling idea that had occurred to me, for Jack Renauld was ushered into the room. Poirot greeted him in a business-like manner. “Take a seat, monsieur. I regret infinitely to derange you, but you will perhaps understand that the atmosphere of the Villa is not too congenial to me. M. Giraud and I do not see eye to eye about everything. His politeness to me has not been striking and you will comprehend that I do not intend any little discoveries I may make to benefit him in any way.” “Exactly, M. Poirot,” said the lad. “That fellow Giraud is an ill-conditioned brute, and I’d be delighted to see some one score at his expense.” “Then I may ask a little favour of you?” “Certainly.” “I will ask you to go to the railway station and take a train to the next station along the line, Abbalac. Ask there at the cloak-room whether two foreigners deposited a valise there on the night of the murder. It is a small station, and they are almost certain to remember. Will you do this?” “Of course I will,” said the boy, mystified, though ready for the task. “I and my friend, you comprehend, have business elsewhere,” explained Poirot. “There is a train in a quarter of an hour, and I will ask you not to return to the Villa, as I have no wish for Giraud to get an inkling of your errand.” “Very well, I will go straight to the station.” He rose to his feet. Poirot’s voice stopped him. “One moment, M. Renauld, there is one little matter that puzzles me.

I struggled for what felt like an eternity to free myself from the tight bonds that held me captive. Through sheer determination, I managed to cut through the ropes around my wrists, restoring feeling to my hands. As I cautiously made my way through the deserted house, I overheard a conversation that sent chills down my spine. The mention of diamonds and secret information piqued my curiosity, but also filled me with dread. It was clear that danger lurked in the shadows, and I knew I had to tread carefully. Time was running out, and I needed to find a way out before it was too late.

The young woman, with a ghoulish mind, was fascinated by the gruesome details of the murder case. Despite my initial disapproval, I found myself reluctantly intrigued by her morbid curiosity. As we entered the shed where the body lay, her high spirits vanished, replaced by horror. She had ignored my warnings, and now she was paying the price. I showed her the victim's fatal wound, a dagger protruding from his back, which caused her to faint. Rushing to her aid, I fetched water and brandy to revive her, realizing that she had underestimated the reality of the crime scene. After she recovered, she begged me to take her away from the scene of death, shaken to her core by what she had witnessed.

"The Villa Geneviève? Just a few steps up this road to the right, monsieur. You could see it if it were not for the curve." The chauffeur thanked him and started the car once more. My gaze was captivated by the woman who remained standing, her hand resting on the gate, observing us. A true epitome of beauty, she was impossible to overlook. Towering in stature, possessing the allure of a youthful deity, her shimmering golden locks glistening in the sunlight, I silently acknowledged her as one of the most exquisite women I had ever beheld. As we ascended the rugged path, I glanced back in her direction. "Goodness, Poirot," I remarked, "did you catch sight of that stunning young woman?"

"Both individuals are currently in a state of suspension. I have shed my skirts and my fabric as well. Why not take a seat?” I calmly settled into a chair. “It appears,” I observed, “that I may have arrived at an incorrect location.” “Unfortunately, from your perspective, that seems to be the case. Miss Beddingfeld, falling into the same snare twice!” “Not the wisest move on my part,” I confessed humbly. There was something about my demeanor that seemed to puzzle him. “You don’t appear to be bothered by what happened,” he dryly remarked. “Would a dramatic reaction from me make any difference to you?” I inquired.

As I turned the corner, I realized that despite having Cinderella's address, I was still clueless about her name. Inside the Salon, the examining magistrate was deep in conversation with the elderly gardener Auguste. Poirot and the commissary acknowledged my presence with a smile and a nod. Taking a seat discreetly, I observed M. Hautet's thorough and detailed questioning, yet he failed to uncover any significant information. Auguste confessed that the gardening gloves were his own, explaining that he used them when tending to a specific type of primula plant that was toxic to certain individuals.

"Upon reflection, it seems that we have overlooked someone," I declared, earning a nod of agreement from Poirot. "Georges Conneau!" Poirot's eyes twinkled as he embraced me warmly. "Enfin! You have arrived. And all by yourself. It is superb! Continue your reasoning. You are right. Decidedly we have done wrong to forget Georges Conneau." Encouraged by his approval, I continued, "Georges Conneau disappeared twenty years ago, but we have no reason to believe that he is dead." "Aucunement," Poirot concurred. "Therefore we will assume that he is alive." "Exactly." "Or that he was alive until recently." "De mieux en mieux!" "We will presume," I continued with growing enthusiasm, "that he has fallen on evil days. He has become a criminal, an apache, a tramp a what you will. He chances to come to Merlinville. There he finds the woman he has never ceased to love." "Eh eh! The sentimentality," warned Poirot. "Where one hates one also loves," I quoted or misquoted. "At any rate he finds her there, living under an assumed name. But she has a new lover, the Englishman, Renauld. Georges Conneau, the memory of old wrongs rising in him, quarrels with this Renauld. He lies in wait for him as he comes to visit his mistress, and stabs him in the back. Then, terrified at what he has done, he starts to dig a grave. I imagine it likely that Madame Daubreuil comes out to look for her lover. She and Conneau have a terrible scene. He drags her into the shed, and there suddenly falls down in an epileptic fit. Now supposing Jack Renauld to appear. Madame Daubreuil tells him all, points out to him the dreadful consequences to her daughter if this scandal of the past is revived. His father's murderer is dead let them do their best to hush it up. Jack Renauld consents goes to the house and has an interview with his mother, winning her over to his point of view. Primed with the story that Madame Daubreuil has suggested to him, she permits herself to be gagged and bound. There, Poirot, what do you think of that?" Poirot looked at me thoughtfully. "I think that you should write for the Kinema, mon ami," he remarked at last. "You mean ?" "It would make a good film, the story that you have recounted to me there but it bears no sort of resemblance to everyday life." "I admit that I haven't gone into all the details, but " "You have gone further you have ignored them magnificently. What about the way the two men were dressed? Do you suggest that after stabbing his victim, Conneau removed his suit of clothes, donned it himself, and replaced the dagger?" "I don't see that that matters," I objected rather huffily. "He may have obtained clothes and money from Madame Daubreuil by threats earlier in the day." "By threats eh? You seriously advance that supposition?" "Certainly. He could have threatened to reveal her identity to the Renaulds, which would probably have put an end to all hopes of her daughter's marriage." "You are wrong, Hastings. He could not blackmail her, for she had the whip hand. Georges Conneau, remember, is still wanted for murder. A word from her and he is in danger of the guillotine." I was forced, rather reluctantly, to admit the truth of this. "Your theory," I remarked acidly, "is doubtless correct as to all the details?" "My theory is the truth," said Poirot quietly. "And the truth is necessarily correct. In your theory you made a fundamental error. You permitted your imagination to lead you astray with midnight assignations and passionate love scenes. But in investigating crime we must take our stand upon the commonplace. Shall I demonstrate my methods to you?" "Oh, by all means let us have a demonstration!" Poirot sat very upright and began, wagging his forefinger emphatically to emphasize his points. "I will start as you started from the basic fact of Georges Conneau. Now the story told by Madame Beroldy in court as to the 'Russians' was admittedly a fabrication. If she was innocent of connivance in the crime, it was concocted by her, and by her only as she stated. If, on the other hand, she was not innocent, it might have been invented by either her or Georges Conneau." "Now in this case we are investigating, we meet the same tale. As I pointed out to you, the facts render it very unlikely that Madame Daubreuil inspired it. So we turn to the hypothesis that the story had its origin in the brain of Georges Conneau. Very good. Georges Conneau, therefore, planned the crime with Madame Renauld as his accomplice. She is in the limelight, and behind her is a shadowy figure whose alias is unknown to us." "Now let us go carefully over the Renauld Case from the beginning, setting down each significant point in its chronological order. You have a notebook and pencil? Good. Now what is the earliest point to note down?" "The letter to you?" "That was the first we knew of it, but it is not the proper beginning of the case. The first point of any significance, I should say, is the change that came over M. Renauld shortly after arriving in Merlinville, and which is attested to by several witnesses. We have also to consider his friendship with Madame Daubreuil, and the large sums of money paid over to her. From thence we can come directly to the 23rd May." Poirot paused, cleared his throat, and signed to me to write. "23rd May. M. Renauld quarrels with his son over latter's wish to marry Marthe Daubreuil. Son leaves for Paris. "24th May. M. Renauld alters his will, leaving entire control of his fortune in his wife's hands. "7th June. Quarrel with tramp in garden, witnessed by Marthe Daubreuil. "Letter written to M. Hercule Poirot, imploring assistance. "Telegram sent to Jack Renauld, bidding him proceed by the Anzora to Buenos Ayres. "Chauffeur, Masters, sent off on a holiday. "Visit of a lady, that evening."
